SPEECH.PARA: (2) Page 5, clause 11, proposed subsection 9a (2), line 31, leave out ``Where,'' insert ``Subject to subsection (3), where''.
(3) Page 5, clause 11, after proposed subsection 9a (2), add the following new subsection:

``(3) For the purposes of paragraphs 26a (1) (d) and (e), and subject to section 26b, a beneficiary under the terms of a trust who is either a natural person not ordinarily resident in Australia, or a foreign corporation, shall not be taken to hold a beneficial interest in the income of corpus of the trust estate except to the extent to which the beneficiary has an absolute entitlement to all or any of such income or corpus.''

Amendment No. 12 relates to amendment No. 3, but both amendments deal with separate clauses in the Bill. A number of points need to be brought out which are quite complicated, and I will try to deal with them as quickly as possible so as not to delay the Committee. Clause 11 of the Bill sets down the circumstances in which trusts and corporations will be required to report to the Treasurer transactions which involve foreigners. The first category, which is set down in proposed new section 9a (1), relates to what are commonly known as the general property and ordinary equity trusts available to people on the financial markets. They are the kinds of trusts which people are investing in every day and which people have some familiarity with. To all intents of the word, they are the kinds of trusts that deal extensively in property, in the share market and in other financial markets in Australia and have literally thousands of shareholders or beneficiaries, depending upon the form in which they have been established. The assets which they hold are identifiable and Australian located.

However, some of the beneficiaries and shareholders of such extensive companies and trusts may live overseas. As a result, clause 11 requires the trustees and corporate managers of those trusts and companies to report to the Treasurer in the event of those people being located. In the cases I have just outlined this clause sets down a description of a substantial interest-that is, when a foreigner holds more than 15 per cent of the corpus or the income of a trust estate or, in the case of two or more foreigners, they own more than 40 per cent of the corpus or income of a company or trust, the transaction is reportable. We are quite happy with that so far.

Let us turn to a discretionary trust, which is dealt with in subclause (2) of clause 11. A different set of circumstances apply. Generally speaking, it is not a large trust. It does not cover literally thousands of beneficiaries or shareholders; rather, it covers only a relatively small number. But that number in itself might be sufficiently large for there to be no direct personal contact between the trustee and the beneficiaries or shareholders. In other words, it could still be, quite clearly, an arm's length arrangement in such a discretionary trust without there being the normal family relationship-as we understand it in this country with domestic trusts-between shareholders and beneficiaries. So that degree of arm's length relationship in a discretionary trust is the reason I have moved amendment No. 3. This is really set down in amendment No. 12 but, as I have mentioned, the two are closely related and have to be read together. That amendment seeks to introduce into a discretionary type trust the same requirement that the Government has included in this Bill as applying to normal or general type trusts.

As we understand it, a discretionary trust is one where the trustees have a discretion to nominate the corpus or the income of the trust in favour of any of the beneficiaries, either to the exclusion of some or to be distributed equitably amongst all of them. That is a matter of pure discretion in the trust deed setting up the trust in the first place. The amendment, therefore, is designed to lift from the shoulders of the trustee in that situation the very onerous conditions, sanctions and penalties that are imposed by the legislation where that person may unwittingly distribute corpus or income to persons who are beneficiaries of the trust but who live overseas and the fact that they live overseas is not known to the trustee. This is designed as a means of ensuring that the law is not used in such a way as to penalise what might be regarded as purely innocent situations where the residence of those beneficiaries is not known. I think a moment's thought would lead us quite clearly to the conclusion that it is impossible to identify who those beneficiaries might be if they are overseas. For instance, we do not know whether the beneficiary--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is opening up a loophole to enable the legislation to be avoided.

—I am just coming to that point. The Minister has made the point that, unless the people who live overseas declare that they are overseas residents, quite clearly it will render his legislation impossible to administer. Unless that fact is known it will not be easy for a trustee to make a decision about whether the Treasurer should be notified in those circumstances. I imagine that it would be quite a simple exercise for any beneficiary living overseas who wished to avoid the effects of this legislation to keep his or her place of residence unknown to the Australian authorities and to set up a nominee situation on the mainland and, in that way, go without detection. I know that there are tracing provisions and what have you within the legislation. However, compliance can still be avoided if a person is of a mind to break the law in that sense and evade totally the effect of the legislation. The legislation is defective, notwithstanding the fact that we do not have much truck with the general principle of it. Because of the conditions which the legislation seeks to impose upon the trustees or managers of corporations managing these kinds of discretionary trusts it means they could be unfairly charged under the penalty sections of the law and in that way could find themselves in a most onerous situation. The purpose of the amendment is to remove that draconian condition imposed by the Government's Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: What we seek to do is to introduce into the conditions surrounding the discretionary trust arrangements the same conditions as apply to general trusts so that, in the event of a beneficiary having a 15 per cent interest at least, which is identified, or in the case of multiple beneficiaries 40 per cent of the corpus and income, it would be reported by the trustee. That is the term that we seek to incorporate in the Bill to remove what I regard as the most onerous conditions upon discretionary trustees-even the most minimal potential beneficiaries of a trust-who would simply be placed in a position in which they might unwittingly breach the law and suffer enormous penalties as a result.

I reiterate my earlier point: this legislation is a bit of a nonsense. If a person living overseas wishes to keep his place of residence or nationality from the Australian authorities and not declare that, obviously he will avoid the impact of the legislation. No doubt there are many ways in which that could be undertaken. So the penalties which are imposed against trustees in either of the circumstances about which I have just spoken are quite silly because we would penalise a trustee for declaring, or not declaring, interest to the Treasurer, but unless it is made known to him by beneficiaries who live overseas that they do in fact live overseas, the trustee is in an impossible position to report to the Treasurer. That is the basic vice of the Bill. It is a huge loophole through which one could drive a horse and cart. We seek to make the Government's Bill rather fairer in regard to the actions and activities of trustees in a discretionary trust as distinct from the other better known type.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although Senator Messner did not mention it, the Opposition's amendments appear to be based on correspondence circulated to a number of members of parliament from Mr Liebler in Melbourne. Mr Liebler has conceded that the inclusion of provisions dealing with the acquisition of interests in Australian urban land by means of discretionary trusts is essential to prevent the easy circumvention of the Government's controls. The legislation currently places new reporting responsibilities on property trust managers but it falls down in one fairly significant point. It does not provide them with the powers that will enable them to comply with these responsibilities. While we believe that it is appropriate to introduce sanctions against trust managers if they avoid their responsibilities, those sanctions cannot be applied fairly unless there are powers which would enable the managers to comply with the requirements of the legislation. Managers of property trusts simply are not in a position a lot of the time to know whether investors are foreign residents or investing on behalf of foreign residents unless they are able to obtain information as to the beneficial ownership of the shares or units. The other obvious way they can do it is if they are in possession of second sight. However, most are not and I think it is a bit unreasonable to expect the managers themselves to bear entirely the onus of that responsibility of reporting.

The amendment is designed to provide trust managers with the ability to meet the notification requirements established in proposed section 26a of the legislation. The manner of getting the information which will facilitate compliance is modelled on section 261 of the Companies Act 1981. It is not something unique. It will provide companies with the ability to obtain information as to who ultimately has the beneficial ownership of the shares. That is important given the nature of the sanctions for non-compliance, which are a fine of up to $50,000 and/or imprisonment of up to two years for a person and a fine of up to a quarter of a million dollars in the case of a corporation. The Australian Democrats' amendment will impose these sanctions for non-compliance on the investor before imposing them on the managers of the trust. It seems to us that there is no point in asking investors to disclose whether they are acting on behalf of foreign investors if there is no penalty for their non-compliance.

Under the legislation before us there is a new responsibility on property trust managers with a sanction attached, but no power is given to the property trust managers to comply satisfactorily with the requirement of the legislation. TALK.START.PARA: —I think the Senate is becoming accustomed to the fact that at this time on each Thursday I have been reporting progress, so to speak, on the highly controversial issue of alleged corrupt practices in banks--
—We can bank on it!

—As Senator Michael Baume says, the Senate can bank on that process continuing each week until such time as the Parliament has adequately addressed the challenges inherent in these very serious allegations. I think the Senate is aware that to date I have done the following things: on 8 December I made a statement in which I passed on to the Senate from constituents a number of very serious allegations of malpractice in banks; I posed a number of questions to the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) and he responded. That process was repeated on 15 December and then again on 15 December I tabled the first of a series of affidavits in relation to this issue, namely, seven affidavits in relation to six allegations of corrupt practices within the Commonwealth Bank. On 2 March I built upon that process by making a further statement and tabling another 20 affidavits in relation to 27 cases which extended beyond the Commonwealth Bank to the banking system at large and those 27 cases, which extended the total number now before the Senate to 35, related to three aspects of alleged corrupt practices in banks.

SPEECH.PARA: The dimensions therefore are threefold. There are allegations relating to targeting and asset stripping, allegations relating to matters of foreign exchange loans and questions of premature foreclosure on rural properties. These are extremely serious allegations and I gave notice on 2 March to refer the matter to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. It was my intention to bring that referral to debate yesterday. However, subsequent to giving notice on 2 March, I have had quite extensive discussions with the Minister for Justice and also with the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and shadow Treasurer, Mr Andrew Peacock, and I have been urged to defer that debate until 5 April. I advise the Senate that that debate will be brought on on 5 April, the proposition being that the whole question of allegations against banks of malpractice and corrupt practices be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. That will now be decided on 5 April.

There has, of course, been a great deal of media attention as a result of the allegations being placed before the Senate and my call for referral to the Senate Standing Committee. As one would have anticipated, the allegations have been denied, initially by the Managing Director of the Commonwealth Bank, Mr Don Sanders, and subsequently by the President of the Australian Association of Bankers, Mr Allan Cullen. I think it was totally predictable that those denials would be forthcoming. It has been stated by both Mr Sanders and Mr Cullen that the Australian Federal Police and the Commonwealth Bank have done a thorough investigation into those allegations and that they are unsubstantiated. I stand by my decision to table the allegations. I do not believe that the examination that occurred between 15 December and 2 March was in any way substantial. Indeed, on 2 March I contacted all six people who were associated with the original affidavits and asked them whether they had, in fact, in the interim period been contacted by either the Commonwealth Bank or the Federal Police and the answer in all cases was no. Whether Mr Sanders and Mr Cullen regard that as a thorough investigation warranting the rejection of the allegations, when the people who have tabled the allegations have not even been approached, I certainly do not.

For Mr Cullen to say publicly that there is no corruption in banking, and dismiss the matter as superficially as that, is about as credible as my saying that there is no corruption in politics, or Commissioner Lewis's saying that there is no corruption in police forces. It is simply not adequate for the Association of Bankers to believe that the allegations can be dispensed with and dismissed superficially at that level. Certainly, it does not satisfy me that he and Mr Sanders have responded in such a manner. These allegations are very serious indeed.

I would like to draw the Senate's attention to the fact that claims by the Government and the police that investigations have revealed no criminality do not mean that there was no deception or corruption. The royal commissions by Fitzgerald, Costigan, Moffitt, Woodward, Williams and Stewart all arose because of police inability to lay charges, but charges resulted from all those commissions and investigations. For example, 12 bank managers either lost their jobs or were charged as a result of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. Double dealing by banks and financial institutions was also exposed by the Woodward Royal Commission into Drug Trafficking and by the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking. So, to say initially that governments do not believe, or the police do not believe, that charges can be laid does not for one minute suggest that these are not matters that should be pursued. In fact, recent history of the process of public investigation would suggest that such initial statements carry little weight at all; and they certainly carry little weight with those of us in this chamber who are determined to pursue these allegations of corrupt practices among the nation's bankers.

Indeed, these allegations strike at the very heart of the most powerful institution in the country. We, of course, are not in the slightest bit surprised that the allegations have been initially denied by that institution. That was totally predictable, but it is no reason why we should be deflected from the process which we have begun. The major parties have undertaken to consider this matter. As I said, I have spoken to the Minister, and I have spoken to the shadow Treasurer, and I am convinced that they now regard these allegations as very serious-not something that, en passant, was introduced to the Senate as a game play between the Australian Democrats and the Government. It was not that at all. These are serious, profound allegations that have been brought to me, as an elected representative, by my constituents and I am honour bound to present them to this chamber and to the Minister. That I have done, and that I will continue to do.

In the interim, in the period between now and 5 April, I expect that the media will pay a great deal more attention to the question of allegations of corrupt practices among bankers. I am advised that one member of the Labor Caucus is intending to raise in Caucus other aspects of banking, which he believes are worthy of attention. I believe that the Minister will carry these allegations to the Caucus, so the Government will give serious deliberation to its position. I am also assured that the Opposition will give equally serious consideration to its position before my proposal to refer the matter, initially at least, to the Senate Standing Committee comes before the chamber on 5 April. I think it is appropriate that the media continues to give this matter very serious attention.

I am also told that there are likely to be a number of public meetings and strategy meetings in relation to these matters. I know that an association has been formed among those who were caught up in the foreign exchange dealing scam and there is now a foreign exchange borrowers association. Indeed, I spoke with the executive director of that association in my office this morning and certainly its members are deliberating further over what they should do. The Senate is probably aware that some 500 Australians were enticed into extraordinary situations by their banks, that more than 500 Australians are now pleading bankruptcy on the basis of advice from their banks which they believe was questionable, and that one lawyer alone in New South Wales, Paul Galli, has pursued 300 cases in that area in the past two years.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to deliver a statement to the Senate today on behalf of the people of Tibet to mark the thirtieth anniversary of their uprising. That anniversary will occur tomorrow, 10 March 1989. This is a plea to the Senate and fellow citizens of Australia for help. As we sit here, another part of the unique heritage, which is our collective planet, lies dying. After 40 years of Chinese occupation of an independent country, Tibet, it seems that its people must still resort to desperate and heroic protests against overwhelming and unbeatable odds in order to be heard by a largely uncaring world. Recent protests in the capital, Lhasa, and everywhere in Tibet say clearly, `Leave us to govern ourselves or let us die'. Since the uprising on 10 March 1959, 1.2 million Tibetans-more than one-sixth of the entire population-have perished and many thousands more followed the Dalai Lama, the former political and current spiritual leader of Tibet, into exile in India. The International Commission of Jurists has recognised that the Chinese practised genocide against the Tibetan nation and the United Nations General Assembly has passed three motions condemning China's human rights abuses in Tibet. A generation of people has grown up in exile speaking Tibetan, born of Tibetan parents and with a Tibetan cultural heritage, yet never having seen their own country. They have no country and no passport and our definition does not enable them to be classified `refugees'. Yet their life and welcome in India and Nepal are highly precarious.

SPEECH.PARA: Today, after 30 years of savage repression, the remnants of the Tibetan people inside Tibet demonstrate popular and spontaneous opposition to their oppressors-the People's Republic of China. In 1949 Mao Tse Tung sent troops to liberate Tibet from feudal theocracy. His Holiness, the fourteenth Dalai Lama, was the first to thank them for waking the sleepy and reticent Tibetan people and their former government to the realities of the twentieth century. His predecessor had founded English medium schools, an army, introduced land reforms and attempted to abolish feudal anachronisms. He died urging his country to modernise or face the threat of invasion and domination. The present Dalai Lama has publicly renounced any theocratic right to govern Tibet and around 1960 promulgated a democratic constitution. Last year he ceded to China control of all foreign policy issues concerning Tibet. Many Tibetan people are very unhappy with his compromise suggestion. In return, he has urged the Chinese to remove their military presence and pass the internal running of the country back to the Tibetans.

For 2,000 years Tibet has been a nation, despite periods when its neighbours-Mongols, Manchurians, Chinese, British and Nepalese-sought to establish influence over the country. On other occasions, Tibetan rulers conquered vast areas of China and other states. They do not lay claim to these territories today. Tibetans, by virtue of their unique way of life and underlying spiritual philosophy, are and for centuries have been peaceful, fun loving, hard working, happy and friendly people. Therefore, it is only extreme and prolonged provocation which leads to such hopeless gestures as the present uprising. The young have never known a free Tibet. Their only hope can be that the rest of the world may hear their plea and urge China to negotiate genuinely for peace in a neutral country with the Dalai Lama and the Tibetan Government in exile. Their only hope is that we speak up against the continuing violation of personal liberty and freedom to hold different beliefs.

A week before his death the Panchen Lama-China's representative in Tibetan affairs; formerly for 12 years a political prisoner tortured in Beijing-spoke out against the excesses of the Chinese occupation of Tibet. Thousands of monastries, cultural objects, priceless ancient books and art work containing unique medical and religious records have been destroyed. He stated that the price Tibet had paid over the past 30 years was too great. We pay tribute to the man, who himself paid an awful price in his intermediary role between China and Tibet, and who, just before his sudden death, dared to voice his criticisms.

These abuses have not ended. Nazi Germany did not oppress its victims for so long-30 years. Documented ongoing human rights violations by the Chinese authorities in Tibet include enforced abortion and mass sterilisation, prolonged detention without trial and torture of political prisoners, continued vigilance by secret police and `listeners' which produces an undercurrent of daily fear and distrust and the introduction of huge numbers of Han Chinese into the country until they have almost outnumbered ethnic Tibetans in their own land. Continuing environmental abuses involve deforestation of the huge pine forests in Amdo. These take 20 years to regenerate because of soil and climate. There has also been mining of uranium and other minerals in locations of spiritual significance in the face of local protests. Also, there have been nuclear tests-the British Broadcasting Corporation's World Service on 8 October 1988 reported that China had conducted its second underground nuclear test since 1984 in north-east Tibet-and the dumping of nuclear waste. With all this provocation the moderation and goodwill of the Dalai Lama's recent five-point proposal for a zone of peace in Tibet is remarkable.

Because of the urgency of the present situation I wish to read the Dalai Lama's message to the people of the world on the thirtieth anniversary of the Tibetan people's earlier uprising-incorrectly termed rebellion by the Chinese-on 10 March 1959. This is the statement of His Holiness, the Dalai Lama:

Today, we pay special tribute to the courage and determination of the Tibetan people, so many of whom have given their lives for our just and noble cause. The suffering our people have been subjected to during these decades mark the darkest period in our long history.

The struggle of the Tibetan people is a struggle for our inalienable right to determine our own destiny in freedom. It is a struggle for democracy, human rights and peace. Most of all, it is a struggle for survival as a people and a nation with a unique civilisation.

The Lhasa uprising of 1987 has greatly stirred the people throughout Tibet. Despite the peaceful nature of this and other demonstrations that have taken place since then, many people have been confirmed killed, and many more arrested. The loss of innocent lives saddens us very much. We not only honour these brave men, women and children today, but also the over one million Tibetans who have died as a result of Chinese occupation. No amount of repression, however brutal and violent, can silence the voice of freedom and justice. The frequent peaceful demonstrations which have taken place spontaneously throughout Tibet over the past years are clear indications of a much larger problem. Unfortunately the Chinese leadership still fails to understand the real situation in Tibet and the extent of dissatisfaction among the Tibetan people. In his last public statement before his untimely and sad demise, Panchen Rinpoche expressed the people's feeling when he said that the price that the Tibetans have had to pay under Chinese rule has been far higher than any benefits they may have gained.

Ours is a non-violent struggle and it must remain so. The killing, imprisonment and torture of peaceful demonstrators or persons who express unsanctioned opinions is morally reprehensible and a violation of human rights as internationally recognised. It can never be justified no matter where in the world it occurs. The condemnation by the international community of these actions will, we hope, persuade the Chinese to abandon such methods. The United Nations General Assembly passed three resolutions condemning China's human rights abuses in Tibet. At this time, when the United Nations is increasingly effective in fulfilling its mission in various parts of the world, I call on the international community to urge the implementation of these three resolutions.

I would like to take this opportunity to express our deep sense of gratitude to the countless people who have voiced concern and expressed solidarity with our people at this critical time. We are also grateful for the conscientious reporting by visitors to Tibet of what they have seen and experienced there.

I am encouraged by the support we have received to our initiative to find a peaceful and just solution to the tragic situation of Tibet. In September of 1987, I presented a Five Point Peace Plan for the restoration of peace and human rights in Tibet. Then, in June of last year I formulated further thoughts that could service a framework for substantive negotiations with the Chinese on the future of Tibet. The Chinese Government has agreed to hold negotiations with us and left the venue and time for such negotiations to me to choose. Although I proposed that the negotiations should start in January in Geneva, the Chinese have, for one reason or another, delayed commencement of the talks. Nevertheless, as the Chinese have, unlike before, become more realistic these days I remain hopeful that the Chinese leaders will see the wisdom of resolving the issue peacefully, by negotiation. I firmly believe a resolution based on the framework proposed by us will not only benefit both the Tibetan and the Chinese peoples, but will also contribute to regional and global peace and stability.

I am aware of the deep-felt disappointment of many Tibetans on the stand we have taken in Strasbourg. As I have stated before, the final decision will be left to the Tibetan people themselves to take.

I have always believed that human determination and truth will ultimately prevail over violence and oppression. Today, important changes are taking place everywhere in the world which could profoundly affect our future and the future of all humanity and the planet we share. Courageous moves by world leaders have facilitated the peaceful resolution of conflicts. Hopes for peace, for the environment, and for a more humane approach to world problems seem greater than ever before. It is imperative that we Tibetans intensify our modest contributions to these changes through our endeavours, both inside Tibet and in exile, for the advancement of freedom, democracy and peace.
With my prayers for the well-being of all sentient beings.

That is the end of the Dalai Lama's statement to mark the thirtieth anniversary of the Tibetan national uprising. I endorse his statement and feel that it is very important that people outside Tibet take note of the violations of human rights which have been occurring there for so long and I think that we should give every support to the Tibetan people in their search for independence.
Sitting suspended from 1.10 to 2 p.m.

ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

—Has the Minister for Resources seen press reports today of the announcement by the North West Shelf joint venturers that they will proceed with the construction of the third $900m liquefied natural gas (LNG) process train? This train is the final phase needed to enable the project to meet contract commitments to supply nearly six million tonnes of liquefied natural gas a year to Japan. The contract is due to commence on 1 October this year through to the year 2009. ANSWER.PARA: It should be remembered by Australians that the total capital costs of the North West Shelf amount to $12 billion. Phase one of the project was to supply natural gas by pipeline to the State Energy Commission of Western Australia-for domestic and commercial consumption in and around Perth. Phase one is operational. Phase two is to supply LNG to Japan from 1989 to the year 2009, as I have said. That is ahead of schedule. The third train is an element in that process.

Senator McKiernan asked what the expected advantage may be from this contract to Australian industry. To date around 72 per cent of capital investment on this project has been expended in Australia. The participants in the North West Shelf joint venturers expect to maintain that in terms of the third train. I repeat that I welcome this announcement by Woodside, and look forward to the as yet unmade decision about a second platform at Goodwyn being made shortly. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer as far as it goes. —I draw the attention of the Minister for Consumer Affairs to the December 1988 issue of Choice magazine and the Australian Broadcasting Corporation television program The Investigators of 21 February 1989. Is the Minister aware of the criticism expressed in these reports about the safety of sunglasses sold in Australia? What action is the Government planning to take to address this criticism?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note the current and long term interest of Senator Zakharov on issues such as product safety. Her question implies, and the article and the television program that she referred to indicate, that there has been some criticism of sunglasses sold in Australia. I should say at the outset that that criticism is somewhat off target. The question of standards for sunglasses in Australia has been on the agenda of this Government for about four years now. In 1985 we introduced one of the most rigorous standards for sunglasses in the world. That standard is currently being revised and I hope some time later this year to be able to update it. The standard was introduced under the Trade Practices Act and applies to sunglasses and fashion spectacles, all of which are made or manufactured in Australia or were imported into Australia after 1 November 1985. The standard also had a number of variations which accommodated some of the existing glasses but did not at all go to the question of safety of sunglasses.

ANSWER.PARA: The Choice article makes two complaints: firstly, that there has been a failure to comply with the standard and, secondly, that there has been a failure to label adequately. In respect of the second point, there is no requirement at the moment for labelling in the way that the Choice article suggests that the standard has been breached. In respect of the first point, the failure to comply, it should be noted that in no case since 1985 has the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs found a breach of the most critical safety requirement of the sunglasses standard; that is, the requirement on ultraviolet transmission. It is fair to say that that is the most critical part of the standard; it is the part which would affect consumers if it were not conformed with. Some of the failures that I have mentioned go to the less critical requirements of the standard; some go to a misunderstanding of the variations and the totality of the standard that was introduced in 1985; and some, I suspect, go to the products that were imported into Australia or made here before November 1985.

The Investigators report also suffers from one basic deficiency. It argued that there was a need for protection from ultraviolet radiation and also called for labelling. In respect of the protection from ultraviolet radiation, ultraviolet transmission limits are imposed on all categories of sunglasses covered by the standard. As I said earlier on, in all cases investigated by the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs there has not been one instance of sunglasses identified as failing to meet the ultraviolet requirement; in fact, all have passed by very wide margins.

As I said at the outset, we have one of the most rigorous standards in the world. In view of national and international developments, we are looking at revising the standard. It is the intention of this Government to adopt the revised standard under the Trade Practices Act when that standard is developed. When reviewing the standard this year, we will be very closely investigating the whole question of a more comprehensive system of labelling sunglasses so that consumers can be directly aware of the sorts of glasses they buy at the time of purchase.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister for Justice confirm that additional Budget allocations for the Australian Federal Police (AFP) will pay only for redundancy and career restructuring and not operational matters? Is it not the case that AFP Commissioner McAulay recently sought additional operational funds from the Government to complete investigations into the murder of Assistant Commissioner Winchester and other major crime and that the Government has refused such funding? Is this not a breach of the undertaking given by the Government after the death of Mr Winchester? Does the Government not realise that such a refusal undermines the confidence and the capacity of the police force in an environment of rising crime and violence?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The moneys sought by the Government by way of extra appropriations, Supplementary Estimates, include money to do with the restructure of the Australian Federal Police and the redundancy offers, some 50 of which were made, resulting from the rationalisation.
—It was 47, was it not?

—Yes, but we have made provision for 50. It depends on how many take it up. Obviously it is a voluntary matter. The fact is that there were other elements in the moneys sought in the Supplementary Estimates-for example, a new incentives package developed by the AFP to offset the cost of transfer of police to sensitive investigatory units based in Sydney. This will be a very important part of the use of those extra moneys and will help very considerably with the operations of the Australian Federal Police in that particularly sensitive post.

ANSWER.PARA: The investigation into the killing of Assistant Commissioner Col Winchester is a matter that is of profound interest and concern to the Government and to the community generally. When the resources that had to be devoted to that investigation were at full stretch, naturally the Commissioner sought, in the whole context of seeking considerably more funds for the Australian Federal Police, more moneys to cover that investigation. The fact is that we believe the Australian Federal Police has the capacity to absorb the cost of that operation within the moneys that are appropriated for their particular purposes. Indeed, I believe that it will be found at the end of the financial year that no major operational matters will be prejudiced by this particular budgetary decision and certainly the safety of members will not be prejudiced by these particular budgetary decisions.

There are tight budgetary controls being exercised within the Australian Federal Police, but I believe that the operational activities and members' safety, which are the key concerns, will not be prejudiced by this allocation of moneys. Indeed, the Government has shown its complete commitment to the Australian Federal Police in terms of the moneys sought in the Additional Estimates, which are very considerable and which will enable it to achieve its objectives not only in the Australian Capital Territory but throughout this nation as it becomes the major investigative agency of the Commonwealth in the law enforcement area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Could the Minister provide us with a summary of the amount of money that we are talking about and the breakdown of how it is to be apportioned?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Federal Police Arbitral Tribunal decision of 1 December 1988 approved a major restructure of the Australian Federal Police. The decision, effective on 1 January 1989, created new incremental classifications and awarded work value increases in the base salaries for members of the AFP. That will amount to $3,800,000. A new incentives package developed by the AFP to offset the cost of transfer of police to sensitive investigatory units based in Sydney has two components-salaries, $192,000; and administrative expenses, $408,000. As a result of the Federal Police Arbitral Tribunal broader salary structure, a number of positions were rationalised to streamline the force into a leaner, more efficient organisation. The additional estimate reflects the cost of redundancy offers resulting from the rationalisation. That amounts to $4,240,000. These are all parts of the restructuring of the Australian Federal Police which, of course, have a major impact on the operational activities of the Australian Federal Police.
—They wanted money to continue the Winchester investigation.

—Senator Hill keeps making a continuous stream of interventions during Question Time. Before the last Budget session I requested from the Federal headquarters of his Party the Opposition's law and justice policy. To show how much he knows about the Australian Federal Police and its restructuring, the policy states that the AFP:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . is also responsible for security and protection functions at Parliament House . . . some diplomatic and consular missions, and specified Commonwealth properties.

That is not the case; it has not been the case for a tremendously long time. It shows that Senator Hill has no understanding whatsoever of the present structure of the Australian Federal Police, nor of the way in which it is being refocused to achieve its national goals and objectives.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs aware of the concern within the community about the threat posed to the Anzac area of Gallipoli by commercial development? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training inform the Senate of the level of fee that would need to be imposed on higher education students if the Government were to meet its commitments to growth in the higher education sector without increasing its own outlays and without the contribution of students through the higher education contribution scheme (HECS)?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the final year of the present triennium, which is 1991, expenditure on tertiary education will be almost $550m higher in real terms than it is now. Most of that increase will come from additional Budget outlays but a significant proportion will be raised by the higher education contribution scheme. Ultimately, students will be contributing around 20 per cent of the cost of their education through the HECS. In 1991 we expect that there will be about 400,000 students in the system. If we assume that 25 per cent of those students are exempt from HECS for reasons of scholarships, in order to get the $550m from the students, each of the remaining 300,000 students would have to pay an annual up-front fee of more than $1,800 a year; that is, if in that short period all the additional expenditure were to be raised from the 75 per cent of those students who would be liable to pay the HECS. All students, regardless of whether they were part time, full time, internal or external, receiving Austudy or not receiving Austudy, would have to pay more up front than is required through the higher education contribution scheme, the repayment of which is income contingent.

ANSWER.PARA: The Opposition has recently claimed that it can match the Government's commitment with a fee of $600. Mr Beale has guaranteed that the fee would not be increased, or even indexed, under a coalition government. Of course, that undertaking is incompatible with the Opposition's very vague undertakings that it will reduce government expenditure. There is a huge credibility gap. In current dollar terms the higher education contribution scheme will raise over $500m when it is fully operational. On the projected student numbers, the $600 fee proposed by the Opposition will raise about $170m. So it is easy to see that there is a credibility gap of the order of $300m or above-it is more like $350m-in this area alone of the Opposition's policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order. The Minister is addressing himself to a hypothetical and distorted version of the Opposition's higher education policy. In fact, the Government's credibility gap will be exactly of the same order in 1991. The Minister should be asked not to proceed further with his answer because it is based upon his own distorted description of the Opposition's position. He should be answering only with respect to factual matters that relate to the Government.
—Order! There is no point of order. I have no power to tell the Minister how he should answer a question.

—I had virtually finished. I just draw attention to the fact that an Opposition that believes that it can get the same amount of money from a $600 fee as a $1,800 charge-even though payment is deferred-is the sort of Opposition that could produce a hypothetical Budget containing a $1,500m internal error.

—Is the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services aware that there is a public debate in the Australian Capital Territory on whether the leader of the Abolish Self-Government Party in the Australian Capital Territory election, Mr Dennis Stevenson, is an Australian citizen? Is the Minister able to give the Senate any information about whether he is or is not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

That was the reason, I think, that a great deal of media interest was sparked off. When we get such queries we do not answer them. Privacy has to be paramount. We do not answer them in a public sense. Certainly, they could be answered in this chamber.

ANSWER.PARA: Our search through our files would not indicate that Mr Stevenson is an Australian citizen, on the proviso that he came here from overseas. If he is Australian-born, nothing will show on my system. That system is never infallible when one checks for someone's citizenship. I suggest to the journalists and everyone else who has a great interest in this matter that they go to Mr Stevenson himself-not that he is the most forthcoming individual. He has not always declared all his associations in the past to allow the electorate to make a full and rational decision in their voting patterns.

Wearing my other hat, as Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, I should say that if Mr Stevenson were not an Australian citizen the whole Australian Capital Territory ballot would probably be invalid. It is quite different from the Wood case inasmuch as this is within the normal course of time for a Court of Disputed Returns. However, if anyone believes that any of the candidates were not eligible, the Court of Disputed Returns would be the best place in which to take up those matters at this stage. I would warn anyone against taking up a frivolous case. Sometimes it costs-as someone found the other day, unfortunately-$27,000. So it can be an expensive process. I enjoyed all the advertisements on television and reading the Canberra Times. I would love another election!

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. I refer to an item in this morning's Canberra Times that the just passed Ozone Protection Bill does not protect the ozone layer but will actually cause further damage, and to the criticism that the Act lags behind other moves to protect the ozone layer. As I am concerned to ensure that Australia should be in the forefront in these matters, can the Minister tell me whether there is any basis to these claims?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of Senator Coulter's press release. No doubt honourable senators who were in the chamber the other day were aware of his contribution to the debate. The press release suggests that he did not learn much from the debate and obviously has some severe misunderstandings as to what the legislation contains. Given the reports that we have received in the last few days from a conference being held in London, Senator Coulter also has a greatly expanded view of what other countries will do with ozone legislation in the course of the rest of this year. He keeps saying that Australia has introduced very weak legislation that will be overtaken by the rest of the world. I said the other day that, bar Sweden, this is the strongest legislation in the world. I am confident that I will be able to maintain that assertion for the rest of this year and into the new one. In fact, a number of countries-and I express some dismay at this-are walking away from taking steps to properly ratify the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer.

ANSWER.PARA: The protocol calls for a freeze on the quantity of the supply of chlorofluorocarbons at 1986 levels from 1989. It asks for a 20 per cent reduction in the supply from 1993 and a further 30 per cent cutback from 1998, giving a total reduction of 50 per cent over 10 years. When we considered the legislation in the chamber the other day it was explained to Senator Coulter many times-not just by me but by Opposition senators-that we are moving twice as fast as the protocol and will achieve that 50 per cent reduction by 1993. It is disturbing that anyone, particularly a senator, would continue to assert what is clearly not the case on the face of the legislation we looked at the other day. Obviously we must wear criticism all the time; I just wish some of the criticism was a little better based than this.

Australia is the only country in the world which has contemplated or put in practice any ban or restriction on exports. Indeed, we have a 5 per cent lessening each year. Australia is the only country in the world to have done that. If we were to implement what Senator Coulter asks for, in terms of an export ban of, I think, 20 per cent a year for five years, we would perhaps assert our moral authority over the developing world but, in fact, we would condemn many nations, particularly those in the Asian region, to a life without any refrigeration or air-conditioning of any kind. While we might rest more comfortably in our beds and suggest to ourselves that we have been holier than thou, the thou that we are holier than would be suffering. I for one would not seek, for some short term political gain here, to inflict any penalty on those less fortunate than people who live in Australia. I reject the many misstatements of fact in Senator Coulter's press release. I just wish people would look at the Bill which we put through on the face of it. When they do that they will see that it is very strong legislation and legislation of which we are justifiably proud.

Does that mean that the Government's tax file number policy is already flawed and that many people will now have made available to them by the Taxation Office numbers that they could use illegally?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

I believe that the Privacy Commissioner, Mr Kevin O'Connor, who has recently taken up his position, has had discussions with the Commissioner of Tax- ation, Mr Boucher, concerning that series of mail-outs. As I understand it, a new procedure has been adopted-although that is probably a matter for the Minister representing the Treasurer-to ensure that those who are to be assisted by the Taxation Office by being informed of their tax file numbers so that they can fulfil their obligations are those who have completed a tax return over the last 12 months as that is the address to which the information will be sent.

They are being addressed by the Taxation Office and, I believe, with the Privacy Commissioner, whose task and role were defined by this chamber. With him we can have confidence that the Taxation Office will exercise greater efficiency and diligence in ensuring the proper distribution of tax file numbers, which is the aim and the wish of those who passed in this place both the tax file number legislation and the privacy legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Will the Minister answer my question? The Minister made a nice little speech, but I asked him whether he agreed with the Privacy Commissioner that many of the 7 per cent of tax file numbers sent to either deceased people or wrong addresses by the Taxation Office will never be returned to that department. Does that mean that the Government's tax file number policy is already flawed and that many people will now have made available to them by the Taxation Office numbers that could be used illegally?

—I believe that in the previous answer I gave sufficient information to the Senate to assuage the very real concerns that were expressed. I will refer any further elements of the question to the appropriate Minister.

—Has the Minister for Resources seen in today's Australian Financial Review an article about the Coronation Hill project in the Kakadu conservation zone which seems to indicate that a trade-off has to be made between the protection of an endangered species and mining? Is the question of mining at Coronation Hill as simple as the advertisement implies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today's Australian Financial Review on page 19 carries a full page advertisement by the operating company, Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP), regarding the Coronation Hill joint venture headed `Platinum, palladium or the pig-nosed turtle. Which comes first?'. This provocative eye-catcher of a title is not only ill-advised, in my opinion, but also misleading as to the content of the advertisement. It sets up an impression in the community that I think is wrong. That ought to be pointed out straight away. This Government does not see the Coronation Hill project as involving a choice between minerals and the preservation of a form of indigenous Australian wildlife. It is not a choice like that. It is not a question of one or the other. We do not see mining development and the protection and preservation of wildlife and the environment as being mutually exclusive.
—Does Senator Richardson agree?
—Yes, he does. I do not believe that BHP thinks that, either. The detail and fine print of the advertisement state:

ANSWER.PARA: The area is also shared by one hundred and four bird species, twenty-two mammal species, forty-four reptile species and thirteen types of frog.
Eminent amongst these is the Pig-nosed Turtle, sole survivor of a family representing around forty million years of independent evolution.
A curious and scarce freshwater dweller, it is found in the South Alligator River.
While this profusion of natural wealth is nothing new in Australia, it does present one of our greatest modern challenges.
Reconciling the economic necessity to develop our mineral resources with the preservation of our unique, rich environmental heritage.

I do not think it was intended by BHP to convey the impression which the headline conveys. For most people, who simply read headlines and not the fine print, the headline juxtaposes concepts which, in my view, is entirely wrong.

Three months ago, BHP published its draft environmental impact statement (EIS) indicating that mining at Coronation Hill is not inconsistent with the protection of the habitat of the pig-nosed turtle, which includes the upper reaches of the South Alligator River system and other Top End river systems. On seeing this advertisement, my office contacted BHP to get its comment on it. I am advised by BHP that its comment is that the advertisement is not intended to convey any incompatibility between the protection of the wildlife species and BHP's proposed mining operations.

At present the EIS is open for comment. My Department will be commenting on it to Senator Richardson's Department shortly, and ultimately a final EIS will be prepared. It will ensure that endangered species are protected and that the environment generally is protected. The Government is committed to those objectives. The project would not proceed if those objectives were subverted in some way. The purpose of an EIS is to find a way in which we can balance both objectives. That is a matter still to be resolved. In the meantime, given this advertisement, BHP would be well advised to sack its advertisers.

TALK.START.PARA: —At Question Time on 28 February Senator Haines asked me a question relating to the Wesley Vale pulp mill. I gave some information in answer to that question at the time. I also undertook to obtain further information regarding the economic analysis by Dr Neville Norman. As Senator Haines and others are probably aware from media reports today, Dr Norman undertook his research as a consultant to the joint venture partners. However, following from Senator Haines inquiry, I asked the Bureau of Industry Economics to examine Dr Norman's analysis. The Bureau of Industry Economics altered the main parameters to test the sensitivity of Dr Norman's results. The Bureau found that the key variable is the forecast growth in prices for craft pulp. Using growth rates for prices ranging from zero to 5 per cent, the Bureau found that the cumulative contribution to the current account to the year 2000 varies from $1.2 billion to $3.3 billion. That depends on the price range for pulp. Therefore, the bottom line is that, even under the most pessimistic assumption of zero growth in prices, the foreign exchange effects are very substantial.
—by leave-Mr President, I claim to have been misrepresented.
—They are always misrepresenting you.

—They are always misrepresenting me. Yesterday I made a very clear personal explanation relating to a misrepresentation by the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, regarding his claim that I intended to sack half the lieutenant-colonels in the Royal Australian Army. I understand that that furphy has been repeated today by his colleague the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, Mrs Kelly. I can assume only that today's gross misrepresentation is not an accident and that it constitutes a deliberate attempt by the Government to mislead the Parliament. I do not know quite what action we can take in this place, but I regard it as disgraceful, although it is not unusual for this Government. The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel further misrepresented me today in answering a dorothy dix question about her new telephone number system, which she launched with the help of two admirals, one air vice-marshal, one general, two brigadiers, a deputy secretary--
—How much did this cost?
—I wonder how much it did cost. It was launched also with the help of a first assistant secretary, together with about 50 assorted hangers-on.
—Mr President, I take a point of order. The honourable senator sought to make a personal explanation about some particular problem of her own, but--
—She is doing it. Don't be so sensitive. You are very touchy today.

—I am not being sensitive; I am not the least bit sensitive. But the Standing Orders provide that if an honourable senator seeks to make a personal explanation it shall be a personal explanation. If Senator Puplick and Senator Hill would stop giggling away like a couple of budgerigars in the first row, listen to what I am saying and look at the Standing Orders, they would understand my point. Senator Newman is debating the question. She is not making a personal explanation.

I have been very well informed about her secret weapon for several months: that the computer equipment for it has cost about $108,000, that the Minister has retained an advertising agency, that she has employed three staff, that she has acquired new office furniture for it and that she plans to spend hundreds of thousands of dollars on advertising in the months to come. I have also known for some time that the Service spouses regard this as a very low priority in terms of the needs of Defence Force families.
—Order! Senator Newman, this is supposed to be a personal explanation.

—As I said, I have also known for some time that Service spouses regard this as a very low priority, the forces regard it as an unwelcome intrusion in the chain of command and the family liaison officers regard it--
—Order! Senator Newman, this is not a personal explanation.

—Mr President, I take a point of order. It is not a personal explanation, and leave will not be granted for this sort of thing in the future if Senator Newman carries on like this. This is an attack on a Government Minister, which honourable senators are quite entitled to make. Plenty of forums are available to do so. But this is not a personal explanation.

I have to convince you, Mr President, that the Minister was incorrect and was misrepresenting me in that direct statement. I am telling you exactly what I knew about the matter.

—I shall not be long. I would have been finished by now.

—The honourable senator may have been. We all know where the line is. The honourable senator knows that she has stepped over it and is starting to take a bit more turkey for her plate than she deserves.

—Mr President, I wish to speak to the point of order. Let me draw your attention to what Senator Ray has put to you. He has argued that this personal explanation is improper because it is taking some extra time to make. According to Senator Ray, Senator Newman is, to use his words, taking a bit of extra turkey to which she is not entitled. Senator Newman has explained to the Senate that she has been misrepresented, and in order to explain to the Senate how she has been misrepresented she is entitled to explain what she knows about the matters which the Minister was accusing her of not knowing anything about. Mr President, I put it to you that, on any fair basis, Senator Newman is simply explaining that she did know and that the Minister, therefore, had misrepresented her by saying that she did not.

SPEECH.PARA: . . . concerned by the conduct of National Party Senator Ron Boswell whom he claims had conspired with the Chairman of the Aboriginal Co-ordinating Council and the State Minister for Community Services Mr Bob Katter . . .

Let me make it very clear to the Senate that that is not the truth of the matter: Aboriginals are capable of making up their own minds in respect of coming down here to lobby against the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition opposes the motion moved on behalf of the Government by the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Robert Ray), and we will move an amendment to it. The Leader of the Government in the Senate referred to senators having to do some extra work. The Government must understand that many senators will probably have to come back here on the Friday night. These senators would be entitled to a travelling allowance. This is what will happen if the Government forces the Estimates committees to sit on a non-sitting day at the beginning of a non-sitting week. I put it to the Government that that is being grossly unfair.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw the Senate's attention to the history of Estimates committees. I think we are all in agreement that Estimates committees perform a vital function. In the past, Estimates committees, under both Liberal-National Party governments and Australian Labor Party governments have met mostly on sitting days. In 1985 Estimates committees first met on 15 April, which was a non-sitting day. Four more days were listed, all of which were sitting days-there were no more non-sitting days-and, in fact, the last two of those sitting days were not used. So in 1985, Estimates committees sat on one non-sitting day, and that was a Friday at the end of a sitting week. The Senate sat from Monday through to Thursday and then there was a full day on the Friday for Estimates committees.

In 1986, the first three days listed were sitting days. The Estimates committees sat after the Senate had adjourned from relatively full days of sittings. The committees then sat on a non-sitting day. This was followed by two days of Estimates committee meetings after the Senate had adjourned-in other words, they were almost full days with Question Time in the mornings. In 1987 four days were listed for Estimates committee meetings followed by one non-sitting day, if required. By 1987 the Government was getting sick of Estimates committees-we were asking too many difficult questions-and it decided to make life very difficult. Estimates committee hearings were listed for two sitting days and two non-sitting days plus an additional non-sitting day if required.

Now we come to this proposal. What the Minister is proposing is that the Senate Estimates committees meet on four particular days, two of which are sitting days, two of which are non-sitting days, and the last one of which, as I say, is the Monday of a non-sitting week. We are suggesting that Friday, 7 April, be substituted for Monday, 17 April. I put that to the Minister as being not unreasonable. It would mean that we would lose a sitting day. No doubt, if the Government wished, the Committees could meet after a short sitting of the Senate on the Friday morning.

I point out to the Government that it set this particularly crazy sitting pattern which we have at the moment. It is the Government that decided that, because of the Governor-General's swearing in, the Senate would resume one week later than it normally would. We have had this crazy sitting pattern imposed upon us. The Government must have known, when it was setting that pattern, that there was a need for Estimates committees to meet. The Government should realise the terrible difficulties it will be imposing on all senators, not only Opposition senators but also Government senators, if it maintains this proposal. Accordingly, I suggest that in paragraph 4 (a) we substitute Friday, 7 April, for Tuesday, 11 April.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is an extra sitting day. Would Senator Lewis give some thought to Monday, 3 April, being the first hearing day? That is the beginning of a sitting week. We may be able to come to an agreement.

—I understand what the Minister is putting to us. The Opposition will try to accommodate the Government. I agree with the Minister that Monday, 3 April, is far better than 17 April. Nevertheless, the Minister is still utilising a non-sitting day instead of a sitting day. The Opposition parties have always been of the view that the Estimates committees form part of the very vital activities of the Senate and, as such, sitting days should be utilised. If the Australian Democrats would indicate to me their attitude towards our suggestion and the alternative being put by the Minister, we may be able to come to some agreement.
