DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON THE NEW PARLIAMENT HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable senators, I table the following reports from the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House relating to proposed work in the Parliamentary Zone: lake foreshore development and lighting within the Parliamentary Zone; and a community based child-care centre. I also table the minority report.

DEBATE.TITLE: LAKE FORESHORE DEVELOPMENT AND LIGHTING WITHIN THE PARLIAMENTARY ZONE

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Puplick)-by leave-agreed to:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate endorses the minority report of the New Parliament House Committee opposing any decision to construct a child care centre adjacent to the old Parliament House until the Government advises the Senate of its plans for the old Parliament House and expresses its intention of exercising its right under subsection 5 (1) of the Parliament Act 1974 to deny approval for such a building to be erected.

I take the Senate back to a report that was presented in May of 1984, the report of the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House, the Committee whose reports are before us today, on the future use of the provisional Parliament House. As I said, that report was brought before the Senate in May of 1984. To go back even further, the terms of reference of that Committee are as follows:

In June 1982 the National Capital Development Commission published its report `Parliamentary Zone Development Plan' in which it noted that, ``. . . in the absence of any decisions about the use of the Provisional Parliament House after it is vacated in 1988 it has been assumed that it will remain in its present form.''

Concurrently it was recognised that detailed planning of the interior of the new Parliament House will be affected by any decisions to incorporate material from the Provisional Parliament House (the existing building) and that logically such decisions should not be taken until the future of the latter has been determined.

It was thus clear that a decision on the future use of the provisional House was an essential step not only in developing an overall plan for the Parliamentary Zone but also in determining which items of historical or artistic merit should be used in the new Parliament House.

A major reason for the uncertainty about the future of the provisional House is the fact that there is no obvious procedure for determining the matter. Furthermore under the Parliament Act 1974 all buildings and works within the Parliamentary Zone must be approved by Parliament.

Because of this uncertainty the Joint Committee proposed to the Minister for Territories and Local Government (Hon. T. Uren, MP) on 6 May 1983, that the Committee's terms of reference be amended by inserting a new clause requiring that the Committee consider and report on the use of the Provisional Parliament House after it is vacated by Parliament.

On 25 May 1983 the House of Representatives agreed to a resolution moved by the Minister that the Committee's resolution of appointment be amended by inserting after paragraph 3 the following new paragraph:
``(3A) That the Committee consider and report on the use of the Provisional Parliament House after it is vacated by Parliament.
On 26 May 1983 the Senate concurred in the resolution of the House.

I am pleased that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) is in the chamber, because the future of that building which is so important in the history of this country is something in which I have no doubt he will be taking a great interest. It is worth noting the recommendations of the Committee presented to the Senate in May of 1984. The first was that the provisional Parliament House should not be demolished. The second reads:

Because of the historical and heritage merits of the provisional Parliament House it should remain basically as it is subject to the modifications required to the southern facade and the roofline to enhance the views of it from Capital Hill.
The third recommendation reads:
The most appropriate future use would be as a museum related to the Australian Constitution, Federation and the Commonwealth Parliament.

The fourth recommendation goes on to deal with the parliamentary museum and the collections that it might have. The fifth recommendation was that the provisional House should remain under the control of the Presiding Officers, advised by a joint committee and with funds to be provided. The seventh recommendation was that the continued long term use of the provisional House by the parliamentary departments was not appropriate. It is clear from the report which was accepted by the Senate in 1984 that the Senate then regarded the building as being of historical and heritage merit. I know the Senate can change its mind, but I cannot believe that it would have changed its view about the historical and heritage merit of that building. The present situation is that the Government, notwithstanding the fact that this report was presented in May of 1984, has failed to deal with the matter of the future of that building. It has failed to tell us what it intends to do. The only rumour I have heard is that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is alleged to think that it ought to be demolished. That, of course, I cannot believe. The last I heard was that the Government would defer making a decision for 12 months or so, and goodness knows when that was.

I personally feel quite affronted that the Government regards the building so lightly. It is important as a tourist facility in the national capital; it is even more important as part of the history of this country. I expected that the Government, as is normally the case, would respond to a committee report within six months of its being presented, at the end of 1984 or perhaps into 1985, as it was quite a big decision. I have waited anxiously for a report on the future of that building. I thought it might be announced on 9 May last year when this building was opened. That would have been an appropriate day, given that it had not been announced before then. I thought the Government might have announced the decision as to the future use of the building when it closed, when we vacated it last year, but that has not been the case. As I said it is a matter of considerable regret.

I recognise that, since this decision of the Committee came before the Parliament, there has been discussion and there is perhaps a fairly widely held view that to restore it to its 1927 configuration would be a reasonable way of presenting it for the future. That could well be regarded as the most viable option. If that were to be the case, to put a child-care centre or any other building adjacent to the building as is now proposed is even more inappropriate. The original building was in the shape of an H, with the two chambers and King's Hall along the front, the dining rooms and other rooms along the back, and the spine across the middle was the Library. The gardens flowed from the sides of the Library out across to the lawns, the areas that are now being talked about. If the building were to be restored to its 1927 configuration, the restoration of the gardens and the surrounding areas would be very much a significant part. Even if that were not the case, those parts which were integral to the use of the building are still quite significant.

Honourable senators may recall that a couple of years ago, because the Government wanted to expand the Parliament considerably, we agreed that it should place a temporary building in that area. A bridge was erected across the road from the provisional Parliament House to the temporary building. I am surprised that that bridge has not already been removed, because I am sure all senators will recall that the basis of its being put there was that it would be removed after the use of the building was concluded. I hope that that will be removed quite soon because it was envisaged that that area was so much a significant part of the building. The point I wish to make most strongly is that nothing should be built in that area until such time as the future use has been determined, and determined by the Parliament. I remind the Senate of the provisions of the Parliament Act 1974, section 5 (1) of which reads:

No building or other work is to be erected on land within the Parliamentary zone unless the Minister has caused a proposal for the erection of the building or work to be laid before each House of the Parliament and the proposal has been approved by resolution of each House of Parliament.

It is for the two Houses of the Parliament to determine what will happen within the whole of the parliamentary zone as defined in the Parliament Act 1974. It may well be that there is a place for a child-care centre outside the parliamentary zone. In fact, the amount of space I can think of near to it but outside the parliamentary zone would mean that that would be a feasible proposition.

I am reminded also as we discuss this matter today that not long ago people wanted to put a child-care centre in the National Library. When renovations and alterations were being made to the Library, space in the Library was made available for a child-care centre. There were people who wanted to run it, to use it and to be involved, but for some reason best known to the Executive at the time, it would not tolerate or contemplate a child-care centre in the National Library. That, too, was in the parliamentary zone. I certainly approved of it. I knew of no-one but the Labor Government who was strongly opposed to its being there. It remains a mystery to me why that was the case. Now we are confronted with a proposal to put a custom-built child-care centre right next to the old building. I plead with the Senate to support our motion that on the basis of the heritage characteristics of that building, and its importance not just to my constituency, the people of Canberra, but to many others as well, it should not proceed until it has been looked at more closely.

When the matter came before the Committee there were a number of other questions that were not answered relating to costs of the building, use of the building and things of that nature. The thrust of the argument that we bring to the Senate today relates, as I have stressed, to the heritage aspects. I do not believe that those who have an interest in the heritage of this country have been adequately consulted. A letter I received from the Chairman of the Australian Council of National Trust indicates that the proposal is of great concern to the National Trust, particularly as it does not seem to have been referred to the Australian Heritage Commission. I wonder what consultation has taken place about building a structure in that area on the tennis courts on the House of Representatives side of the old Parliament House. It has been the home of the Parliament for 60 years and needs to be treated with more concern than has been shown to the present time. I could go into the question in more detail as to where a child-care centre might be sited and why it might be put there, but they are matters that are not the concern of the Senate. It is the areas specifically within the parliamentary zone which pursuant to the Parliament Act must be approved by this Parliament.

I cannot understand why or how the Cabinet last November, as I think the Minister told us when we asked questions about it last year, suddenly out of the air decided to put a child-care centre then and there in the grounds of the old Parliament House. Certainly the question of child-care facilities relating to this building has been of interest to a number of people for quite a long time. That is not in dispute. It could have been solved much sooner had the Government agreed to the child-care centre being based at the National Library, but somehow that was not to be. I invite honourable senators to read the minority report which has been presented. The Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House determined that it should write to the Government to ask for information about the old building and its future use, but on party lines the Government determined not to go along with being certain as to what would happen to that building before any structure be placed on either side of the building.

I remind the Senate of the report with which I started my remarks, that presented in May 1984, and would point to its terms of reference and to the conclusions that the Committee reached. I refer the Senate to the report, which does not give details as to the need for a child-care centre in the area and details of cost, which did come up, but those matters were insignificant compared to the heritage issue. The minority report makes it plain that it is the heritage issue and not child-care that we are talking about. I urge the Senate to support the motion I have moved, and require the Government to tell us what is happening before any structure, child-care centre or anything else, is put in that vicinity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate endorses the minority report of the New Parliament House Committee opposing any decision to construct a child-care centre adjacent to the old Parliament House until the Government advises the Senate of its plans for old Parliament House and exercises its right under section 5 (1) of the Parliament Act of 1974 to deny approval for such a building to be erected.

I strongly support Senator Reid's remarks. I endorse her view that this is not a matter of opposition to the concept of a child-care centre. I think that it is absolutely vital for the Senate to recognise that that is not the basis for opposition.

I can understand why there is a feeling of frustration and anger among some people in this place, and not only senators and members but workers in this Parliament and in the parliamentary zone, at the fact that proposals for the establishment of a child-care centre have continually been either fobbed off or ignored or pushed aside-and particularly, as Senator Reid said, by the Government in not going ahead some time ago with a proposal that seemed rational, and I have found no coherent reason why it should not have gone ahead, to have a child-care centre in the National Library. This has been going on for a long time. The need for child care in the parliamentary zone was first identified, as the Committee was told, in 1981 and has been raised in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) community by the Status of Women Caucus Committee, the child-care subcommittee of the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House, and the Australian Council of Trade Unions. The ACT Children's Services Program Planning Committee also identified the parliamentary zone as a high need area for child care. There is a universal and accepted view that there is a clear need for a child-care centre of some kind-whether it is community based or not is a question that can be discussed later.

In passing, it is worth reflecting on whether a community-based child-care centre is appropriate in an area where a great deal of the demand will be not from the community, but from tourists visiting the area on a temporary basis. In fact, the recommendation to the New Parliament House Committee included the strong suggestion that major users would be the children of tourists. Added to that factor is the clear problem of priorities which would have to be applied for people using that child-care centre, if it were a community-based centre with the funding coming out of the Australian Capital Territory's appropriation.

Let us face it: the demand, as we understand it, and as we have understood all previous recommendations on the matter, relates to the special needs of people working in the parliamentary zone. At the Committee meeting we were told very clearly that there were no plans whatsoever for any priority to be given to people working in the parliamentary zone. We were told there were no arrangements at all to establish priorities. In fact, because it would be a community-based centre, it would have to be available to people passing through the parliamentary zone on their way to their workplaces or elsewhere. In other words, the child-care centre would bear no specific, detailed or necessary relationship to the parliamentary zone except that it would be available to some extent, we know not what, to tourists, and it would be available to some extent, we know not what, to workers in the parliamentary zone.

There was an estimate of $700,000 for the total cost of the project. We were told that construction would start in the first half of 1989-in effect almost immediately, if it were to start in the remnants of this financial year. For that to be done, it seems to me we should be seeing an argued request and a detailed proposal presented to this chamber under the terms of the Parliament Act 1974. We have not seen that proposal yet. It would seem to me that we are entitled to ask what fees would be charged or what priorities would be imposed, on users. These are matters which I think merit a debate. It seems to the Committee-as is mentioned in the minority report-that it is inappropriate for any construction to take place in the parliamentary zone if it does not have a strict and direct relevance to that zone. From what we were told at the New Parliament House Committee, the proposed child-care centre to some extent may have a relationship, but would not necessarily, or strictly, have a relationship, to the parliamentary zone itself. This was because people within the parliamentary zone may not even have a priority of use for that child-care centre.
It is worth pointing out exactly what the minority report says, because this resolution endorses the minority report. I quote from the report:
While recognising the need for a child care centre in or near the Parliamentary Zone . . .
One will notice that that does not necessarily say what kind of child-care centre. It does not say that it will be necessarily community-based, but just says `a child-care centre'. To continue:

. . . we are concerned about the Heritage implications of any new building erected ``adjacent'' to the old Parliament House, particularly if the old House is to be restored to its 1927 state in an appropriately landscaped area.
As a result, a decision on a suitable location should not be taken before the Government advises the Committee of its proposals for the future of the old Parliament House.

I interpose that I totally support Senator Reid's comments that the Government has taken an inordinately long time to make a decision about what will happen to the old Parliament House. I fear that the decision not to make a decision on this issue rests upon the expectation that if the matter is left unattended for long enough, and if the building deteriorates enough, then there will be no option but to demolish the old Parliament House. I am very suspicious of the delays introduced by this Government in the making of such a decision. I have no confidence in the Government's goodwill or good intentions in this matter. There is no excuse for failing to make a decision and I look to the motives and I am concerned about those motives.

When this New Parliament House Committee was forced into a decision to spend $50,000 for the construction of a new Speaker's chair for the new Parliament, it was on the assurance from the Government that the previous chamber would be maintained as a parliamentary museum. That was the justification for not bringing that historic and significant Speaker's chair to this building. As Senator Reid has pointed out, what has happened since then? Absolutely nothing, except that I imagine the Speaker's chair has now gathered a fair bit of dust.

Are people being taken to see the historic Speaker's chair? Are school children being given the opportunity of seeing the chamber in which so many historic and significant events in Australia's political history have taken place? No, they are not. This Government has done nothing. It is no wonder that members of the Opposition are suspicious of the motives of the Government in this matter, because we know there are some people who take the view that the building should be demolished. There is no doubt that the longer this Government takes to decide on this issue, the greater will be the weight behind the claims of those people who will say, `Look, it would cost too much to refurbish it; it will cost too much to restore it. Now we have allowed it to fall into disrepair, it will be simply too expensive to restore. Therefore it should be demolished'. If that were to occur, it would be an absolute disgrace. No doubt Senator Richardson would seek not to allow it to happen, because of his clear concern for the heritage of this country. Maybe he will get rolled again. He seems to have been rolled quite regularly recently.

TALK.START.PARA: —I haven't got rolled once.

—The honourable senator has a good imitation of getting rolled. I think it absolutely vital that this Senate express its very strong views about the significance of the heritage involved in the old Parliament House. I continue to quote from the minority report:

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the report of the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House, which has just been tabled, and support the Australian Democrats' opposition to the motion put forward by Senator Reid. I have not been able to study this somewhat slim report in detail because I saw it only a very short while ago. I am well aware that people in the Parliament have been working on the issue for a number of years. We are looking at two important issues-child care and the maintenance of our heritage. There is a long history of need for a child-care centre to be placed within the Parliamentary Triangle. As Senator Reid said, when the new National Library was built there was a strong move to have a child-care centre included there.

SPEECH.PARA: Everyone who works in Parliament House has very special needs. We work long hours but very often we do not know the hours that we will work. I would consider, for example, our Hansard reporters, who work so hard for us in this chamber. They do not know what time they will get home at night. Even if those people have home-based child-care arrangements for their young children, arrangements can go wrong and emergencies do arise, so there is no doubt in my mind that there is a need for child-care for people who work here both on a regular and a casual basis.

I gather that for security and other reasons there would be problems in locating a child-care centre in this building. I have also heard that the display area close to Parliament House was also considered as a location but was considered inappropriate because of the lead from car exhausts, as well as other reasons. Last year I was a speaker at a forum on child-care needs in the Australian Capital Territory. The forum was attended by a large number of people. They made it plain to us all that there was a need for more community-based child-care centres in the Territory. Those who work within the Parliamentary Triangle will be able to make good use of a child-care centre to be located as proposed.

I turn now to the second issue at stake-that is, heritage. As yet there appears to be no certain proposed use for the provisional Parliament House. As I stated in my valedictory speech, the provisional Parliament House is a very important part of our heritage and requires a use that will bring members of the Australian public and overseas tourists to the building. I believe that there is general agreement that the additions which were made to Parliament House after 1927 will be taken down so that at last we will see it in its original state-smaller, but with that original integrity.

There is also a problem because of asbestos in the ceilings of the building. It will cost a great deal of money to settle that problem. I suppose that the reason people are not being shown the Speaker's chair at the moment is that the asbestos situation is being looked at. It is very dangerous for anybody to go inside a building where particles of asbestos might be floating around in the air. Mesothelioma is a deadly disease. We are now seeing its results in Western Australia. I would not wish that disease to be inflicted on anybody.

Looking at the plan regarding the provisional Parliament House and the proposed child-care centre, we see that the provisional Parliament House is flanked by gardens. On the Senate side is the original rose garden and tennis courts. I am not sure what is going to happen to those tennis courts. On the House of Representatives side there are the additional buildings and tennis courts, which are situated further away from Parliament House, in the corner of the garden at the back of Parliament House. It is proposed to place the child-care centre at the back of those tennis courts. It appears to be approximately the same distance from Parliament House as the Lobby restaurant. The Lobby restaurant is located near the opposite corner towards the front of Parliament House. The restaurant was designed by a top architect and built in the early 1970s. It certainly has a sensitive architectural design and fits in with the landscape extremely well. I hope that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, who is responsible for both heritage matters and Australian Capital Territory matters, will assure us that any child-care centre to be built on this site will be equally architecturally sensitive and will fit into the landscape as well as the Lobby restaurant. The child-care centre will be screened by trees and will be in that back corner, so I do not believe that it will detract in any way from the aesthetic value of the area.

The heritage issue is always interesting. The problem is always how do we maintain the best of our heritage while at the same time providing for our contemporary needs? We do not approach the issue in a very clever way in my home city of Perth. We tend simply to tear down our heritage and replace it with what one might call a simple solution. In this case, however, we can meet both objectives. We can maintain our old Parliament House as part of our heritage and, at the same time, cater for the needs of present and future generations by providing child-care within the parliamentary triangle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak about only two aspects of the report by the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House relating to a community based child-care centre in the parliamentary zone. Firstly, I want to address certain heritage questions and, secondly, I intend to say something about some of the outrageous remarks made by Senator Dunn on this matter. I start with her gratuitous attempt to impute a certain view to Mrs Sullivan, the honourable member for Moncrieff, by congratulating her on not signing the report. Mrs Sullivan, as I made clear previously, was not present at the meeting at which the majority and minority reports were settled. As to Mrs Sullivan's commitment to child-care in the Australian Capital Territory, and in the Parliamentary Triangle in particular, Senator Giles has already alluded to Mrs Sullivan's work in this area over many years. The attempt gratuitously to impute a view to Mrs Sullivan in regard to the minority report is typical of the way Senator Dunn conducts herself, both in this place and as a parliamentarian in general.

SPEECH.PARA: I am unimpressed when Senator Dunn comes in here and starts waffling on about how child-care fees at the centre will be charged according to a person's income. For somebody who was prepared to exist on a senator's salary and expect the public of New South Wales to subsidise her housing costs, who was prepared to live in cheap, subsidised accommodation when there were genuinely needy people in the community who actually needed subsidised housing-until she was sprung in the public media; otherwise, presumably, she would have been perfectly prepared to continue with her rent subsidy, her public subsidy for her housing costs-to come in here and say that, of course, fees will be based on people's capacity to pay--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I do not believe that this is relevant to the current debate.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—I note that it is only the question of relevance and not the question of accuracy that concerns Senator Dunn on this occasion. Her contribution needs to be seen in that light. Senator Powell's attempt to say that the Opposition seeks to disguise the nature of the minority report by drawing, as it were, the red herring of heritage questions because we are basically opposed to child-care centres can be adequately rebuked and refuted in exactly the same way as can some of the comments of Senator Jenkins-by actually looking at what the minority report says. The minority report opens with these words:

SPEECH.PARA: While recognising the need for a child care centre in or near the Parliamentary Zone . . .

The signatories to the minority report-Senator Michael Baume, Senator MacGibbon, Senator Reid and the Hon. Don Dobie-have made it quite clear in the opening words of the minority report that they recognise the need for a child-care centre in or near the parliamentary zone. The minority report then goes on to make recommendations. It does not recommend against the construction of a child-care facility in the parliamentary zone at some stage in the future. All it says is that we ought to have from the Government a clear statement of what the Government intends to propose to the Parliament about the future of the provisional Parliament House before the final decision on the child-care facility is made. Because the minority report is only five paragraphs long, I propose to read it. It says:

While recognising the need for a child care centre in or near the Parliamentary Zone, we are concerned about the Heritage implications of any new building erected ``adjacent'' to the old Parliament House, particularly if the old House is to be restored to its 1927 state in an appropriately landscaped area.
As a result, a decision on a suitable location should not be taken before the Government advises the Committee of its proposals for the future of the old Parliament House.

We regret the majority decision not only to agree to the proposal immediately but also to reject our request for the Government to provide an urgent response to the Committee on the future of the old Parliament House before construction proceeds on the Child Care Centre.

We are also concerned that the proposal, which specifies a community based centre funded from the A.C.T.'s Federal Government allocation, contains no details of estimated demand for a publicly funded centre, of charges to be applied or priorities to be followed in accepting children, many of whom it appears will be from parents having no involvement in the Parliamentary Zone other than it being on, or near, their routes from their homes to their places of work.
In our view it is inappropriate for any construction to take place in the Parliamentary Zone that does not have a strict and direct relevance to that Zone.

That concludes the minority report. Let me go over what it actually says. It says, firstly, that the minority is concerned about the heritage implications of any new building erected adjacent to the old Parliament House `particularly if the old House is to be restored to its 1927 state in an appropriately landscaped area'. The erection of a child-care centre will reduce the capacity of the Government to make certain determinations about the immediate vicinity of the old, provisional Parliament House: how it should be preserved, how it should be altered and what the restoration and landscaping arrangements might be. It will be circumscribed by the building of this facility prior to that determination. The minority report says:
. . . a decision . . . should not be taken before the Government advises the Committee of its proposals . . .

That is not unreasonable, given the amount of time that this Government has had to advise the Parliament and the Committee of what its proposals are for the provisional Parliament House. The report then draws attention to the fact that not only would the majority-that is, the Government members of this Committee-not agree to this proposal; they would not even agree to ask the Government for an urgent response to the question of what was to be the future of the provisional Parliament House. The report then makes certain other comments which are not immediately relevant to the question of the heritage values which are at stake here. I want to make it quite clear that Senator Reid's motion proposes:

That the Senate endorses the minority report of the New Parliament House Committee opposing any decision to construct a child-care centre adjacent to the old Parliament House until the Government advises the Senate of its plans for the old Parliament House and exercises its right under section 5 (1) of the Parliament Act 1974 to deny approval for such building to be erected.

In other words, the motion does not say that the minority report should be endorsed because it recommends that there should not be a child-care centre; it says that the minority report should be endorsed because a decision should not be made until-`until' is the word actually used-the Government has told us what it proposes to do with one of the most important parts of Australia's national heritage. In terms of the urban landscape, the built environment, the provisional Parliament House is now the single most important building or structure in respect of which the Government has, without any complications about Federalism or whatever, a direct national responsibility to advise this Parliament as to what its proposals for the future are. I turn to the paragraph of the majority report which says:
In November 1988 Cabinet agreed to the establishment of a community based child care centre adjacent to the provisional Parliament House.

I simply draw the attention of honourable senators to the fact that this is an executive government decision about a matter which properly, under the legislation, is one the Parliament should be taking. It is the Parliament's responsibility, as a result of the Parliament Act 1974, to determine what happens within the parliamentary zone. Here we see a Cabinet decision that something will occur. It is not a decision to ask the Parliament; it is not a decision to ask for debate in the Parliament; it is a decision of the Cabinet that something will occur, despite the fact that the legal responsibility for making decisions about the parliamentary zone rests not with the Executive but with the Parliament. It is of some significance to indicate that this is a clear example of the Cabinet-the executive Government-saying, `Regardless of the position of the Parliament at law, we will make this decision and, of course, having made it, we know that we will be able to enforce it because, through Caucus, we have the numbers to do so and to overturn the rights of the Parliament'.

I could go on at some length about this particular matter. I do not propose to because, in fact, it is just as important today to require the Government to indicate its view on Senator Walters's Bill, which will come before the Parliament, and to ensure that we know exactly where it stands. It will be interesting to see whether all of the great proponents of the value of child-care to women in this community will take the same view about the question of the right and responsibilities that the Parliament has towards women in terms of the issue of pornography. This afternoon we will be provided with a very good opportunity to test whether all of those who want to claim that they support the rights of women to have access to child-care will similarly stand up to defend the rights of pornographers to exploit women. It will be interesting to see whether they all come out on that matter within the course of the next couple of hours.

The heritage issue is an important one. Let me say to Senator Jenkins that I am surprised to see her rejecting the proposition that we should not make a decision about work within the parliamentary zone until such time as we know what the future of the provisional Parliament House is. I accept that she has a genuine concern about heritage values and heritage questions. All the minority report says is, `Do not make this decision until we know what will be the fate of the old building'. What would Senator Jenkins say if, following the construction of the child-care centre, a proposal to demolish the wings added to the provisional Parliament House so as to take the building back to the original design-and I agree with her in that respect-were rejected because the asbestos that would be loosed into the atmosphere as a result of that work would prejudice the health of people in the child-care centre? That will be an interesting question for Senator Jenkins to turn her mind to when it comes up.

All the minority report has sought to say is that this Government has been dilatory in indicating what the future of the provisional Parliament House is to be. Here we have a method of ensuring that it tells us the answer to that question. We have said, `We will not approve this particular public works proposal until that information is given to the Parliament'. I think that is eminently fair and reasonable, and I think Senator Reid's motion should be supported on that basis.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I am not as fascinated with Senator Dunn's domestic arrangements as other senators are, but I suspect that this will not be the last time that the honourable senator puts this matter on record. I doubt very much that we have heard the last of the honourable senator's domestic arrangements, so the honourable senator should be ready.

SPEECH.PARA: Today we have been debating the minority report on the provision of child-care facilities in the Parliamentary Triangle. I want to cover a number of points that have been raised during this debate. I am surprised at the continual references to heritage that we have heard in this debate-as if the construction of a child-care centre will in some way diminish or ruin the nation's heritage as contained in the provisional Parliament House building. I do not believe that it is beyond the wit of the combined resources of architects, the Joint Committee on the New Parliament House, the Heritage Commission and the Government to construct a child-care facility on the area formerly occupied by the gymnasium, near the bowling green-which is not in the provisional Parliament House building but near it-in such a way as to in no way interfere with the heritage value of the site. We will not build some seven-storey glass tower; I do not think anyone seriously suspects that we would. So, obviously, any architect drawing up plans will have to do so sensitively, and I am sure that will be done. When the plans for this have been made final by the architect they will be shown to the Joint Committee on the New Parliament House.

There is no intention on the part of the Government to proceed in some way without having the Committee look at those plans. I give the Senate an assurance that the Heritage Commission will be giving advice to the Committee and the Government on those plans once they are ready. There is no intention to attempt to hide what might be done. Clearly that is not possible anyway. It is being debated in the Parliament. Everyone may be assured that the consultation will be wide. For what it is worth, my own undertaking is there. In no way would I be supporting a building that detracts in any way from the heritage value of the site. I have not seen a plan yet so I have nothing to approve or disapprove, but I will be anxiously awaiting that report.

The demand for this type of facility has been around for many years. It was first raised in 1981; so it did not happen yesterday. I do not intend to reveal all that happens in Cabinet but this was discussed on a number of occasions. While I cannot say that it was like the 14-hour discussion we had on the Lemonthyme last year, it was nonetheless a long discussion. The decision reached in the end was unquestionably the right one. Many sites were looked at. We did not just look at one or two sites.

TALK.START.PARA: —All Cabinet decisions in the end are right, aren't they?
—All Cabinet decisions are unquestionably supported. I am suggesting that on this occasion the right decision was made and it is a pleasure to support it.

SPEECH.PARA: There were many sites looked at. The Minister, in presenting his report to the Cabinet, looked at 15 sites; not one but 15. We were having a very close look at all the possibilities. The Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) has been urging the Government for some time to establish this facility. The Children's Services Planning Committee of the ACTU established it as a high priority years ago; not yesterday. Surely, with the growth that we are going to see and that we have already experienced in tourism in recent years, the need for the facility cannot possibly be disputed.

One wonders what the minority report is all about. I have heard many Opposition speakers contribute to the child care debate over the years. Clearly, there is a division on this question in the Opposition as, indeed, there is on many questions. Some Opposition senators, like Senator Reid, undoubtedly have a view that there is a place for child-care. I suspect that is Senator Puplick's view as well. But equally there is no doubt not only that a great many Opposition senators have no commitment to child-care, as evidenced in this proposal, but also that the Opposition parties have no commitment to the principle of child-care whatsoever.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.

—It is true. It is even the Opposition's policy now. What we are really seeing is just another way of getting in the road of a child-care proposal which the Australian Capital Territory obviously needs. The need for it cannot be disputed. It is not the case that those using this facility will be part of some unnecessary middle class extravagance. Indeed, there are many workers in the Parliamentary Triangle on very low wages. That, if for no other reason, is a good enough reason to proceed with the decision that has been taken.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government cannot support the motion to adopt the minority report in this case. The minority report is fatally flawed in too many ways. But most importantly, the ACT needs this facility, and after Saturday and the results we have seen, I do not think we should attempt to inflict any more misery on the ACT than it has already inflicted on itself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-It is interesting that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) should have concluded on that note about the election in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) last Saturday. That is the point I wish to make in concluding this debate. There was an election in the Australian Capital Territory last Saturday for an Australian Capital Territory Government. Three days later the Minister is sitting here telling the people of the Australian Capital Territory that, notwithstanding the fact that he claims to be committed to self-government for this Territory, he is prepared, even now, after that election, to spend $0.7m of the ACT's budget, as Senator Giles has just told us, for these 40 child-care places. It will come from the ACT's budget and the ACT Government will have absolutely no say in whether this is where the money should be spent or how it should be spent.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister must also know there is a deficit in the ACT budget. But notwithstanding that, the Minister rushes on, even after an election. He keeps spending the Australian Capital Territory's money and does not leave it as a matter to be negotiated with the ACT Government. If the Minister was spending his own money it might be a different matter; but he is not. He is placing this facility in the parliamentary zone where, as the Minister has just stated, the ACTU has been urging for it to go. Perhaps at last we have actually got to the truth of the matter in that little snippet. It is going where the ACTU wants it at the ACT Government's expense. That perhaps is the whole story.

TALK.START.PARA: —The ACTU has never argued for that site. It has argued for the need and that is all I have said it has argued for.

—How it would know about it, I would not know. The whole argument has been on the question of the heritage value of the old Parliament House. The Minister suggested that we were saying that a child-care centre would diminish the heritage value of the site. That has not been stated in this debate. What we have said is that that building and its environs are important and have been thought to be important by the Senate since the report of the Joint Committee on the New Parliament House in relation to the future of the old building was presented here in 1984. The Senate has just done a back-flip on that. The future of that building and how it is to be presented to the public should be determined before any other decision is made as to the environs, not the other way around. We have not said that there should never be anything built anywhere near it. We just say that the future of that building and its environs should be determined before any decision is made. There may be buildings put there; there may not. But that is not the point.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been interesting to listen to the contributions today from those who pretend to be environmentalists and to be concerned about the heritage of this country. When one scratches them a little, one finds that their concern is not very deep. That has been another aspect of the debate that has been worth noting. But perhaps the most significant point that finally came out was from the Minister's own mouth, that, notwithstanding the Government's apparent commitment to self-government, it is not prepared to stop spending the ACT's money when it suits it.

That the motion (Senator Reid's) be agreed to.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION AND DEPARTMENT OF ABORIGINAL AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the special audit report of the Auditor-General on the Aboriginal Development Commission and the Department of Aboriginal Affairs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

The special report of the Auditor-General on the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) and the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, which has been tabled today, is dynamite; it is devastating. All the discussions on Aboriginal affairs that have taken place since the Budget was brought down last year, in the whole of the Budget session last year, and all the controversy that surrounded the issue at that time have now been brought together in a most damaging and most dramatic report to this Parliament by the Auditor-General. Just about every one of the issues which were referred to the Auditor-General and which required special investigation has now been commented on by the Auditor-General in a way which demands the urgent attention of this Parliament. In fact, if the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) does not read this report tonight and demand the resignation of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), he will be derelict in his duties. The calls last year for the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to resign were constantly shrouded in political controversy. Because the issues were raised by politicians, they were seen in that light, as being part of a political agenda. But the Senate now has before it a report to the Parliament by the independent Auditor- General that points out the dramatic seriousness of this whole issue.

We must at all times consider that the essential issue that must be addressed is to ensure that service delivery to Aboriginal people is the first priority. Nobody on this side of the Parliament has ever denied that that should be the first priority in the conduct of Aboriginal affairs-service delivery for people throughout Australia in special and often dire need. Of course, there are many fine staff in both the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Aboriginal Development Commission. Probably the great majority of them are fine servants who are seeking to do their job. But obviously last year the whole administration of Aboriginal affairs under this Minister, Mr Hand, got totally off the tracks. We have not had much time to look at this report, which was tabled only an hour or so ago in the House of Representatives, but any senator who has had the time to peruse it will be horrified at the findings which have been brought down. Let me go through some of the comments contained in the Auditor-General's synopsis at the front of the report:
. . . Audit has encountered difficulties in obtaining timely information from the Commission.
That is the Aboriginal Development Commission. It continues:
At the exit interview . . . the Commission was represented by Mr Adams QC and relatively junior staff . . .

Many of the findings related to deficiencies in meeting statutory requirements and it appeared that several projects funded were outside the legislated powers. The advice of the Attorney-General's Department in this area conflicted with that of Mr Adams QC.

. . . Audit considers that the Commission should improve accountability for the funds spent on the enterprise program by disclosing information about the people and organisations who receive the funds, and those who have been enabled to engage in self-sustaining business enterprises. It should also be more careful when providing funds to ensure that it meets the requirements of the business enterprise provisions of the ADC Act. There is also a need to differentiate more clearly between social and economic assistance, and improved training of participants and project monitoring.
What have we been saying and debating for about six months in this place? The synopsis looked at the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, and this shows some mal- administration:
. . . Audit believes the standard of administration the review has revealed is lower than acceptable and that remedial measures are required.
Further down, dealing with grants and grant projects, the report says:
. . . Audit recommended that there be greater oversight of the financial operations of the Land Councils.
In talking about the review of the grant programs, the report says:
Working Parties were to be, or have been, set up to remedy deficiencies but-
and this is the important part-
the results were more in the way of expectations than achievements.
Further on the Auditor-General comments on the lack of liaison between Federal, State and local administrations and no coordination of funding:

Audit has found the same in its review of Aboriginal and Torres Strait organisations. Funding has been provided from various sources in isolation from each other and Audit recommends that some remedial mechanisms be introduced.

The Auditor-General talks about the staff of his own office, who since the Prime Minister instituted this inquiry back in October have had to work under very heavy pressure. I would again commend those staff. An important point made in the report is as follows:
They-
that is, the staff of the Auditor-General-
had to contend, in some cases, with a relative lack of co-operation not seen before from an official body and with the intervention of Queen's Counsel.

I raised a question on that matter 10 days ago in this place to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Tate, about the particular intervention where the QC and officers of the ADC had accused the Auditor-General's office of racism, unprofessional conduct and incompetence. No wonder we see those sorts of comments now coming through in this very important report. It turns to dozens of particular examples. I do not want to take the time of the Senate now to recanvass each of those issues, but there are whole issues that will have to be addressed.

One particular area on which the Auditor-General has commented is that in the time available to him he has not been able to complete and to finalise many of the references and issues raised. On page 5 he comments:
The report omits findings in respect of Baruwei Enterprises at Katherine, Northern Territory. These will be reported later, after the ADC's response is received.

The Baruwei Enterprises went into liquidation last week. If I had had time today in Question Time, I would have addressed this very important question to the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, on this issue: is it a fact that $2.6m in public moneys, through the ADC, have been invested in Baruwei and that additional funds in the order of $600,000 were allocated by the new ADC Board appointed by Mr Hand in June 1988 to cover working capital required following misappropriations by senior staff? What are the repercussions of this type of thing? Obviously the responses did not get to the Auditor-General, there was not time, and the company has failed. That sort of example points up that there will be repercussions from this failure in remote and small Aboriginal communities right around Australia. There will now be increased prices and lack of supplies in Aboriginal communities. No doubt it will adversely affect the nutrition of Aboriginal children in that area. Is it any wonder that we see continually the sorts of examples raised in this report?
Let me make another couple of quotations from the report. In a comment in one section of the report the Auditor-General says:
Audit doubts whether the Parliament intended that Commonwealth funds be used to enable its officers to engage in business even on a part-time basis.
He is referring there to a number of the involvements of other people. He continues:

Conclusions regarding the business enterprise projects. This audit has shown that . . . there were serious defects in the particular enterprise projects queried by Senator Tambling and other members of Senate Estimates Committee E. There were also serious defects in many other projects examined in the Audit. The Audit disclosed that ADC's largest enterprise project, Yeperenye Shopping Centre, suffered from a fundamental flaw under the Act.
Let me draw attention to what is said on page 62 of the report:
In view of the findings of this audit, the Government and the Parliament may wish to review the business enterprise provisions in the ATSIC Bill.

I would remind the Senate that we saw tabled last week in this place the report of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs which looked into the whole administration of Aboriginal affairs. The minority report, tabled by Senators Peter Baume and Boswell, concentrated on, and highlighted, those particular inadequacies in legislation. Here we have the Auditor-General inviting the Parliament to review the provisions of legislation which has come before it. Under the heading `Compliance with Grant Conditions', the report states that in relation to complying with grant conditions:
Audit found that some grant funded organisations have consistently failed to comply with grant conditions . . .
Under the heading `Management of Aboriginal Organisations', the report states:
Audit identified evidence of poor management and non-compliance with grant conditions by some of the grant funded organisations.

There are many specific examples and this report will obviously take time to digest. The challenge has to be on the Prime Minister, not on Mr Hand. Mr Hand no longer has any credibility in the Aboriginal community or constituency. He no longer has any credibility in the Australian community. This whole issue must be addressed by the Prime Minister.

The Senate Select Committee came in with similar recommendations last week-40 recommendations from the majority report and much more credible recommendations in the minority report from the Opposition members. It is interesting to note that, in all of the debate in the last six months on this entire issue, Mr Hand has portrayed himself continually as a champion of a cause and it has only been that cause that he has continually pushed. He is supposedly one of the leaders of the left faction of the Australian Labor Party. Not one member of the left faction of the Labor Party in this Senate-except Senator Bolkus on one occasion, who stuffed it up-has stood up and defended him or has stood behind anything that Mr Hand has said. That is important and indicative of where this issue is with regard to the Labor Party and the Labor Caucus.

Very obviously, the proposal for the new Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission legislation, which was going to be a big umbrella to embrace this great cauldron of problems, was being pushed continually through the Caucus by Mr Hand and by Mr Hawke. They must accept the responsibility. Mr Hawke must accept the responsibility and immediately sack Mr Hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I addressed the Senate this morning on a matter of privilege, I mentioned that I was concerned that witnesses giving evidence to the Auditor-General did not have the same protection as witnesses appearing before the Parliament. I had wondered whether the Auditor-General would be able to obtain adequate information on which to base a proper report.

SPEECH.PARA: Even on a cursory reading, the report which we have had in our hands for a short time-45 minutes or so-is an indictment of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC), of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) who runs the Department and of the Government of which he is a part. It is a very sad document for one to have to look at.

The whole concept of ministerial responsibility, as we practise it in a Westminster system, requires that a Minister of state, who has under his or her control the various portfolio agencies, is in the end responsible if those agencies fail to observe the law or fail to do their duty. Even on a cursory reading of a few pages, the report of the Auditor-General makes it clear that such a failure has taken place.

This report requires that Mr Hand resign. It requires that he resign if he, as Minister, cannot explain how agencies under his control have failed so consistently, and so lamentably, to obey the laws of this land, to obey the requirements of the Audit Act and why they have cooperated so little with the Auditor-General.

I refer honourable senators to page 2 of the Auditor-General's report, where he discusses his investigations as they related to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. For the information of honourable senators, I will quote from the bottom of page 2 where, in thanking his own officers from the Audit Office, the Auditor-General goes on to say:
They had to contend, in some cases, with a relative lack of co-operation not seen before from an official body-
I emphasise `a lack of cooperation not seen before from an official body'-
and with the intervention of Queen's Counsel.
It is quite apparent that the portfolio agencies resisted the attempts by the Auditor to get to the bottom of the mess.

Honourable senators may not recall that the Auditor-General, Mr John Taylor, is a highly respected officer who was formerly the permanent head of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. Mr Taylor brought to his task not only his expert knowledge on which he was appointed Auditor-General but also the knowledge and experience which he gained as permanent head of the Department. He knows the Department, he knows the portfolio agencies. He understands them and he has reported that his officers had to contend `with a lack of cooperation not seen before from an official body'. If Mr Hand cannot explain that claim satisfactorily, that in itself is reason enough for him to be removed from the portfolio. That is unacceptable behaviour from a Minister of the Crown when faced with an inquiry of this kind ordered by his Prime Minister.

The report reveals that the Aboriginal Development Commission has failed in a number of areas. The failures have been due, and can be related almost entirely to, the new appointees-those appointed by Mr Hand after he sacked the old Commission in May of 1988. His new appointees are the ones who are criticised in this report. The Auditor says that the ADC acted outside its Act, outside its legal authorisation. He says that the ADC failed to provide information as required, and when required, to the Auditor-General to carry out this inquiry. He says that the ADC attempted to impede the Auditor-General in the performance of his duty.

I want to illustrate some of my concerns, only by reference to four of the matters which were raised. The first is the question of certain loans which were made to Mr Ray Robinson of Charleville. To put it mildly, Mr Robinson is a colourful figure in Aboriginal affairs in Australia. I will say no more than that. I see you nodding, Mr Acting Deputy President; you come from Queensland. The Auditor-General sets out in his report a chronology of the various loans and defaults in those loan repayments made by Mr Robinson. The Auditor concludes by saying, at paragraph 2.3.14:
ADC's comment were sought-
I interpolate that they were sought on a number of matters which had been raised in relation to Mr Robinson-
on 16 January 1989 but had not been received at the date of preparation of this report.
On a matter relating to a series of highly questionable loans and highly questionable procedures, information simply was not provided when and as required by the Auditor.

The second matter I wish to raise concerns the funding of the Tranby College for negotiations on a proposed Aboriginal treaty. The Auditor sets out the Prime Minister's announcement on 12 June 1988 at the Barunga Sports and Cultural Festival in the Northern Territory. He sets out the subsequent decisions of the ADC, largely under its acting commissioners appointed by Mr Hand in May, to provide $500,000 to Tranby College. The Auditor sets out that $420,000 of this money was to go to Tranby College and $80,000 to the Island Co-ordinating Council (ICC) in the Torres Strait.

One of the acting commissioners, Mr Getano Lui Jr, is the Chairman of the Island Co-ordinating Council. He was also an acting commissioner of the ADC involved in the decision to provide funds to himself. I refer honourable senators to those sections of the Auditor's report where it is made clear that both the application for, and the acquittal of, funds was unsatisfactory for the ICC. In relation to the decision as a whole to provide $500,000 for treaty negotiations to Tranby College, the Auditor has this to say, and I will quote two paragraphs. On page 15, paragraph 2.3.35 states:
In Audit's view, the Board's decision was ill-considered. There was no application from Tranby to ADC and there was no formal submission from ADC staff to the Board on the matter.
I remind the Senate that $500,000 is involved. The Auditor continued:
ADC had not previously made grants to Tranby. The Board did not satisfy itself that Tranby and ICC were suitable for the purpose and that the amount of $500,000 was appropriate.

This is the Auditor-General of the Commonwealth offering his concern in the understated language of official documents. We can see the extent to which he was appalled by this decision to put $500,000 out without an application, without a proper submission, without proper staff assessment, to an organisation that had not received the funds before. It is an amount which the Auditor did not feel was appropriate. Paragraph 2.3.39 states:

Audit put it to ADC in January 1989 that the payments to Tranby and ICC were grants of financial assistance of a kind not clearly authorised by the ADC Act. Audit suggested that, to resolve the doubts, ADC should seek a formal notice in writing from the Minister under sub-section 8 (g) of the Act to give ADC the function of assisting in the treaty consultations.
I interpolate here that I was once Minister for Aboriginal Affairs.

TALK.START.PARA: —And a good one, too, if I may say so.

—Thank you, Senator. I say to honourable senators that I am quite aware of the fact that there was doubt as to whether funding for treaty negotiations was a function which had been conferred upon the ADC. I was aware of it when I was Minister and Mr Hand should have been aware of it now. The Auditor was quite right to draw to the attention of the ADC that it was probably acting outside the powers which have been given to it. Paragraph 2.3.40 states:

SPEECH.PARA: In a detailed reply on 1 February the ADC argued that the payments were wholly justifiable and provided a further legal advice from Mr Adams who confirmed his earlier advice that the payments were within ADC's powers. Audit referred the legal advice to the Attorney-General's Department which disagreed with Mr Adams' advice and expressed the opinion that the payments could not be regarded as coming within ADC's powers under section 24 or the other provisions of the Act.

So here we have prima facie evidence from the Auditor-General that the provision of $500,000 by an ADC stacked by Minister Hand was probably illegal. That should give concern to all honourable senators.

I want to raise two other matters, the first of which concerns the Woden Town Club. Firstly, it is made quite clear at page 17 that the first application which was received, and for which provisional approval was given, involved funding of an enterprise which had Mr Phillip Hall in it. Everyone associated with Aboriginal affairs knows about Phillip Hall. I would say, to put it politely, that if I were selling something to Mr Phillip Hall I would want him to pay me in cash.

TALK.START.PARA: —In advance.
—No, at the time of the transaction.
—And before you delivered.

—Before I delivered. Mr Phillip Hall has a colourful reputation. That funding was not proceeded with. The Auditor's report goes on to make quite clear that the Minister, Mr Hand, knew, because of a briefing document he received in May 1988, that a loan guarantee was going to be given for the purchase of poker machines and he would have known that there was a possibility of that loan guarantee being called on and, therefore, he knew that the Commonwealth may have had to put up money for the provision of poker machines for the club. I mention that because it was the issue of poker machines on which Mr Hand later based his decision to sack Mr Perkins.

SPEECH.PARA: I note with some sadness that the Auditor reports on the next page that Mr Perkins failed to disclose certain relevant interests for some months, though he eventually did so. On page 18, in paragraph 2.3.57 and the subsequent paragraphs, the Auditor sets out with clarity and detail his understanding of the reasons why the funding of the Woden Town Club was inappropriate and why the ADC failed in its duty to adhere to its own requirements of acting with due care by funding this project. This is contained in the Auditor-General's report which we have only had 45 minutes to look at.

The last matter to which I wish to draw the Senate's attention at this stage is the question of the Oasis Hotel in Walgett. There are Aboriginal people around Australia in the direst need, without clean water and living in appalling housing conditions. If the ADC is going to choose to put money into hotels, into clubs such as the Woden Town Club or into the purchase of poker machines, that certainly indicates some perverse set of priorities. However, the ADC decided to fund the purchase of the Oasis Hotel. I draw the attention of honourable senators only to page 23 and to the conclusions which the Auditor draws on this sorry matter. He stated:
As indicated above, Audit doubts whether ADC's considerable financial assistance to Gamilarai for the hotel was provided in the manner required by the Act.

Can honourable senators believe that? This is another occasion on which the commissioners of the ADC have acted in a way not covered by the ADC Act. These are Mr Hand's specially picked acting commissioners, put in to give him the numbers. The next paragraph states:

The outcome is that, to date, no Aboriginals have been enabled to engage in business to the point of self-management and self-sufficiency. ADC informed Audit that this was carping criticism which denied the value of the experience gained and disregarded the long-term benefits. Audit remains of the view that the amount of some one million dollars of public funds applied to the hotel could and should have been spent more carefully and productively.

In the short time in which we have had this report I have not had time to go through the many other matters it deals with, but it is quite clear that it is a fine and honest report. It is a tribute to John Taylor and to the officers of the Audit Office. It is a very honest and hard hitting document. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had but moments in which to read this special audit report of the Auditor-General and therefore have read only limited samples of it. SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday I moved a motion in respect of answers which had not been provided to me by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) or the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), who represents the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in this place, notwithstanding the fact that the questions had been asked of the Minister eight weeks ago. I can understand the reluctance of the Department to provide the Minister with answers, or the reluctance of the Minister to provide Senator Tate with the answers, because those answers cast a great indictment upon the Department.
