The figures are here and they are available, yet the Department is clearly covering them up and is not prepared to make them available to the Senate.

Of more immediate concern is the fact that answers to questions asked of Senator Tate and given by him in the Senate on 6 December 1988 are clearly wrong. Either Senator Tate was lied to by departmental officers or they are so incompetent that they have not the slightest idea of the activities and functioning of their own Department. I asked Senator Tate:
Is the Department enforcing financial rules and guidelines for the administration of these grants?
His unqualified answer was yes. On page 102 of the report we find these comments by the Auditor-General:
Audit found that some grant funded organisations have consistently failed to comply with grant conditions and Departmental action to overcome deficiencies has, in some cases, been unsuccessful.

The Department acknowledged the problem and stated that the reduction or cessation of funding to these organisations would cause extreme hardship to the Aboriginal communities being served by them. However, in most cases action taken to resolve problems had protected Commonwealth funds.

Audit identified evidence of poor management and non-compliance with grant conditions by some of the grant funded organisations. The problems were also recognised by the Department and corrective action was taken.

We have the Auditor-General telling us that financial rules and guidelines for the administration of the grants were not complied with and that the Department recognised it and acknowledged it, yet Senator Tate told us on 6 December that the Department was enforcing financial rules and guidelines for the administration of these grants. I asked Senator Tate:
. . . are grants still being made to organisations who presently have unacquitted grants?
Senator Tate said:
Yes, but only after careful consideration of all the circumstances . . .
Of course, we have learnt that that is not the case. To quote the Auditor-General, one of the major problems is apparently this:
there may not be the skill amongst the grant recipient personnel to handle the situation to the required standard . . .

I have raised before in the Senate this matter of the responsibility of the Department to employees of communities in receipt of grants. To this point the Department has said that it is a responsibility exclusively for the recipients-for the communities-and not for the Department. In other words, the Department has been quite happy to have $13 1/2m of taxpayers' funds outstanding, unacquitted, and to leave the management of those funds exclusively in the hands of employees about whom it is not prepared to make any judgment. I also asked Senator Tate on 6 December:
What is the Government doing about these unacquitted grants?
Senator Tate responded:
It has been normal departmental practice each year to focus on the acquittal of grants made in the previous financial year when audited financial statements became available from auditors.

It is as if there were some natural, ongoing process for the acquittal of grants each year. We find that absolutely nothing has been done. In respect of the acquittal of grants, the Auditor-General says:

All grants are required to be acquitted by a duly delegated officer with authority also being delegated for the abandonment of follow-up action to obtain acquittance of a grant and/or to approve the use of surplus funds. Although high priority is currently being given to this task many grants made since 1983-84 remain unacquitted and Audit was advised that a number of such residual grants cannot currently be acquitted due to loans by organisations, severe audit qualifications, etc.
The acquittal of grants is further complicated where the grant monies cannot be clearly identified in the financial statements.

Two examples are given where the grants and the funding for the organisation from other sources are mixed. The truth of the matter is that, on the basis of the Auditor-General's report, the answers given by Senator Tate in the Senate on 6 December were untrue and had no relevance to fact. As one looks through this report one can only draw the conclusion that the Department of Aboriginal Affairs is totally out of control; that it is run by a Minister who is totally incompetent, unable to understand good management, unable to get on top of the portfolio, and unable to understand what proper accountability is. When referring to compliance with grant conditions the Auditor-General says:

There were deficiencies noted in relation to both the general and specific conditions. The most common deficiencies concerned the timeliness of receipt of financial statements, the information content of the statements, and the timing and format of the performance indicators. There was a lack of evidence of follow-up by the field officer concerned, and there was no evidence that the release of funds had been delayed . . .
When I asked Senator Tate why 151 grants in Western Australia had not been acquitted, he said:
In the first place, the non-receipt of audited statements is particularly critical in remote areas where auditors are few in number and other matters are often given greater priority.

Other matters are often given greater priority than the accountability of $13.5m in Western Australia alone. As at 31 December 1988, $67.8m of taxpayers' funds was not accounted for, not explained and not acquitted because the Department judged, as did the communities, that there were higher priorities.
We are told by the Auditor that there has been a lack of follow-up by field staff and a lack of action by the communities. We note that Senator Tate said:
These deficiencies are more frequently of a minor nature.

He said that deficiencies of a minor nature were responsible for the grants being unacquitted; yet the Auditor-General told us that they were matters of major moment, of significance and of consequence. When seeking to make assessments as to whether or not the grants were being applied for the purpose for which they were intended, the Auditor told us:
The performance indicators in a lot of cases did not provide the Department with information to enable it to assess whether the project was meeting its objectives.

In other words, the Department did not have in place a program, policy or system which allowed it to assess whether or not the funds were being used for the purpose for which they were intended. It is not without significance to note that in Western Australia, when we had this absolute imbroglio, confusion, chaos, incompetence and, in some cases, corruption, the departmental head was Cedric Wyatt, who for his sins was promoted by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Gerry Hand, to the position of General Manager of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC). At a time of apparent crisis in the ADC, when new, competent and efficient management was needed, it got a personally hand-picked appointment who had reigned over the Department in Western Australia, which the Auditor-General referred to in the report in a most scathing way. I put it down as nothing higher than gross inefficiency and incompetence. It certainly reflects on the Minister's judgment in his choice of people. It indicates to me that he is concerned more about the politics of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs than he is about the Aboriginals involved and the assurance that they receive the funds which are allocated by the Department.

It is not without significance that when I-not once, twice or thrice, but on numerous occasions-raised problems of incompetence and mismanagement in Western Australian communities, referred to audit reports, read figures into the Hansard record and demonstrated to the Government that there were major problems in the Department of Aboriginal Affair in Western Australia, neither the Department nor the Minister wanted to know about it. I could not get a response. Eight weeks after asking fundamental questions-such as, `What grants are unacquitted?'-I have not received the answers. The Minister and the Department do not know. But 30 seconds after turning to the Auditor-General's special report I read the answers. I asked the Minister why the grants were not acquitted and after eight weeks he still does not know. Yet the Auditor-General, in his brief and efficient report, was able to tell me. When I asked Senator Tate whether or not the departmental officers were sufficiently skilled to deal with the matters-the matters being 151 unacquitted grants-Senator Tate answered yes; not with qualification or a suggestion that there was some doubt. He said without qualification that the departmental officers were sufficiently skilled to deal with the matters before them-the matters contained within the report which reflects badly on those same officers.

When I raised in this Parliament the fact that one employee of an Aboriginal community had clearly and grossly misappropriated funds for his own purpose and written cheques out for himself as unrepayable loans-a cute way of doing business, I might say-I was told by the Minister that it was not a matter for the Department; it was a matter for the community involved. When I asked the Minister whether he or the Department accepted any responsibility for the competence, efficiency or integrity of the employees of these communities, I was informed that that was a matter for the communities concerned. In other words, what we are being told by the Minister is that, in respect of the hundreds of millions of dollars which are provided through grants appropriated by this Parliament to Aboriginal communities, the management of those funds and the responsibility for their accountability rest exclusively in the hands of employees selected by the communities and are not matters which impinge upon the responsibilities or concerns of the Department.

Almost without exception, the five pages of questions-25 questions and 92 subquestions-asked of Senator Tate on notice in December last year are answered, in either a general or a specific way, in the Auditor-General's report. Yet the Department does not have the answers. What an indictment of the Department when it cannot tell us what money is outstanding, to whom it is outstanding, why it is outstanding and under what circumstances it is outstanding. The Department does not know who owes it money. Yet one can go to the Auditor-General's report and find out precisely. In respect of the efficiency of the Department in Western Australia in its own internal audit, which I have questioned on a number of occasions, the Auditor-General says:

Apart from a recent visit to the Derby and Geraldton Regional Offices by departmental officers seconded for the purpose, no internal check or internal audit has been conducted in Western Australia since 1986.
There has not been one single internal audit into the affairs or finances of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs in Western Australia since 1986. The Auditor-General tells us:

Audit considers that the absence of satisfactory internal check-internal audit coverage has contributed to the deficiencies within the Region and recommends that appropriate remedial action be taken to institute a more effective coverage in the future.

In other words, the Auditor-General is telling us that the Department has failed in a primary responsibility; it has failed to have internal audits. The only internal audits that took place, took place in Derby and Geraldton as a result of crises there which even this Department ultimately was forced to deal with. Those reports were done by Mr Lyne and Mr Dunlevy between 15 and 25 August 1988. The reports were of the most indictable nature. They reflected in the most gross way upon the Department's efficiency and competence. What has been done about it? Absolutely nothing has been done about it. We cannot get answers from the Department or from the Minister. After eight weeks, the Department still has not provided the answers to fundamental questions.
The report states in respect of compliance with grant conditions:

Audit found that some grant funded organisations have consistently failed to comply with grant conditions and Departmental action to overcome deficiencies has, in some cases, been unsuccessful . . . Audit identified evidence of poor management and non-compliance with grant conditions by some of the grant funded organisations.
In other words, there are very real problems in the Department in Western Australia and absolutely nothing has been done about them.

In conclusion, I note that today, Thursday, is the last day of this sitting and we shall not be sitting for another three weeks. It is not without significance that, every time there is a report pending which has an odour or stench of corruption or incompetence about it which will without doubt embarrass the Government and reflect upon the Minister, the report is introduced into the Parliament in its dying days so that it can escape proper scrutiny, examination, questioning and, most importantly, proper debating. The Government, wilfully no doubt, has introduced this report now so that it has three weeks to compose itself, to compose answers and to find excuses as to why Mr Gerry Hand has presided over an incompetent Department, a failed Department, and yet is determined to press on with restructuring, which can only plunge the Department into further chaos.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to commence my remarks on the report of the Auditor-General, the special audit report into the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) and the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, where Senator Crichton-Browne left off. This report, which was tabled in the Parliament today, was completed, I note, on 17 February. It has been tabled today in the Parliament an hour or so before the Parliament is to rise for three weeks. It is a report of the gravest magnitude. It is the most damning indictment one could ever read of the administration of a department and its agencies by a Minister. The fact that the Government has seen fit to table this report only in the last hour or so of a two-week sitting, with a three-week break to come, is an absolute disgrace. The reasons are patently obvious. It is a purely political ploy to try to divert the parliamentary heat away from this report in the hope that it will dissipate in the next three weeks in which the Parliament is not sitting.

SPEECH.PARA: It is obvious that will not occur. This report, the most damning and damaging indictment I have ever read of the administration of any department by any Minister, will not go away. I expect-indeed, I demand-that between now and the Parliament's resumption in three weeks time there will be a new Minister of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs because no Minister could remain a Minister of the Crown after having been indicted in the manner this report has done.

I come from Victoria. Over the last few months I have witnessed an example in Victoria of what has been occurring at the Federal level on the part of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) regarding his patronage and protection of an incompetent Minister. In Victoria over the last few months we have had the disgraceful debacle, until it was resolved by Mr Fordham's resignation, of a Premier trying to protect a Minister-in this case it was the Deputy Premier-in the face of the most obvious and damning indictment of his administration of a major area of funding in my State, namely, the Victorian Economic Development Corporation. It was only by the efforts of diligent people that in the end, and months too late, that final action was taken by the Deputy Premier, Mr Fordham himself, because he realised that the heat was so hot he could no longer stay in the kitchen. The same applied to the Premier, who felt the heat increasing day by day.

I say to the Prime Minister: Prime Minister, if you do not, on the basis of this report, demand the immediate resignation of your Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand, and, if he does not give you that resignation, if you do not sack him immediately you will bring on your head and on your Government's head a smell and a smear that will stay with you until the next election, as quickly as that may occur. This report is a report of the gravest magnitude. I do not propose, nor are we on this side of the chamber in a position, to go into all the details of the report in this debate. The one thing that is certain is that this report will not go away; it will be debated fully in the Parliament and elsewhere over the period ahead. Given the very limited opportunity we have had to have a look at this report this afternoon, some things have become immediately obvious. As I have said, it is a very damning report. It is the most damning report I have ever read of any government administration. The critical point about it is that the problem has not suddenly emerged. There is no way that the Government, the Prime Minister or the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs can say that they were not forewarned. I turn to page 2 of the report. Right at the very start it says:

While no large and complex organisation is without fault, Audit believes the standard of administration the review has revealed is lower than acceptable and that remedial measures are required. The finding is consistent with past audit findings.

In other words, this is not something new; this is not something that has just emerged in recent months. It was given a higher public profile late last year in a series of Estimates Committee E hearings, in particular, but it has also arisen in other ways.

Mr Acting Deputy President, you are a member of a committee that has been looking at aspects of the administration of the Department. You know, as we all know, that this is a sore that has been festering for a long time. Not one thing has been done until very recently to attempt to correct the grave deficiencies that have been patently obvious to everyone, including the Aboriginal communities themselves. For years the deficiencies have been patently obvious for everyone to see. The real tragedy of this is that the losers are the Aboriginal people of Australia themselves. They are the sufferers. Hundreds of millions of dollars have been squandered each year without accountability and in ways which have benefited the supposed recipients, namely, the Aboriginal people of Australia, to only a minor degree.

This report goes to the heart of what is needed for the efficient utilisation of funds for the betterment of the Aboriginal communities. The report makes it absolutely clear that that has not happened and that those communities have been the sufferers as a result. I would like to raise a couple of specific subjects. Firstly, I refer to the provision of half a million dollars to Tranby College, supposedly for the conduct of negotiations for a treaty with Aborigines. The record of the decisions within the ADC to provide these funds is contained on pages 12 to 16 of the report. These paragraphs contain some extraordinary statements. They say that Mr Perkins, in his capacity at that time of, I think, Acting Chairman of the ADC, moved at the July 1988 meeting of the board of the Commission that $500,000 be provided for the conduct of negotiations in relation to the proposed treaty. Then, at the August meeting of the Commission board, the Acting Deputy Chairman, Mr Dobson, reported that he had attended meetings of the National Coalition of Aboriginal Organisations at Framlingham in Victoria which had been paid for from the $43,000 which had been provided to Tranby a few weeks earlier. Paragraph 2.3.22 of the report, on page 13, states:

After some discussion at the Board meeting of budgets and controls regarding the remainder of the $500 000, Mr Perkins remarked that funding must be . . . tightly bound, so that the accounting does not rest with individuals. He said that Tranby College was not known as the apex of an administrative body; all accounts must be audited so that it can be proved that funds were expended properly.
He also advised that Tranby College was negotiating with Cuba and Nicaragua to send students to those countries to study and it might not be wise for the ADC to be involved with that institution.

TALK.START.PARA: —What page is that on?
—That is page 13, paragraph 2.3.23. It says further that Mr Perkins:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . suggested that the secretariat office for treaty negotiations be based in ADC's Sydney office instead.

So at least Mr Perkins had an awareness of the extraordinarily sensitive political issues involved. Here was the Commission giving $500,000 to a college that was negotiating with Cuba and Nicaragua to send students to those countries to study. What did Mr Perkins say? He said, `Gee, that would be a pretty sensitive political issue. We will try to take it out of Tranby. We will hide it all. We will get around that by basing the secretariat for the treaty negotiations in the ADC's Sydney office instead'. But he did not get his way. Paragraph 2.3.24, states:
After further discussion, the Board, on the motion of Mr Perkins-
so he must have seen that he was on a loser-
approved that the remainder of the $500,000 be made available as follows:
$377 000 to Tranby to establish a secretariat ($100 000) and for the conduct of four meetings ($277 000) in different regions of Australia . .

Also, $80,000 was to be used for other purposes, and some money had already been expended. So, despite the awareness within the Commission that Tranby College was obviously a totally inappropriate place, on administrative and political grounds, for the location of the secretariat, it was located in Tranby College. I guess we can only speculate why it was located there. But, in my book, one pretty fair speculation is that pressure was brought to bear by Mr Dobson and others who are connected with Tranby College as well as the National Coalition of Aboriginal Organisations, which uses Tranby College as a base, to funnel the money that way.
The next damning statement in the report in relation to that aspect comes in paragraph 2.3.26, in which it is stated:

With regard to the proposed secretariat for which ADC approved a grant of $100 000, ADC asked Tranby to provide itemised budgets of proposed expenditure. In September 1988 Tranby provided a proposed budget totalling $100 000 and a document on the proposed secretariat.
I reiterate that the purpose of the secretariat was to be involved with the treaty negotiations. Despite that, paragraph 2.3.26 further states:
The document indicated that the secretariat would organise meetings for the National Coalition of Aboriginal Organisations to `enable consultation on important issues, i.e. ATSIC-
this is nothing to do with the treaty-
the ``proposed'' Treaty, Royal Commission etc.' The document made no further reference to the treaty. The Coalition would determine the agenda for meetings on policy or social and economic issues.
The next two paragraphs are very illuminating as well. Paragraph 2.3.27 states:
Tranby's formal Acceptance of Offer of the grant was signed on 27 September 1988 by Mr Kevin Cook (Member of Executive) and Mr Kevin Tory (Chairman) . . .
They signed in those capacities. The paragraph continues:
Audit inquiries disclosed that the Chairman is Mr John Short-
I hasten to add that he is no relation-

not Mr Tory. ADC's Principal Legal Officer pointed out in October 1988 that Tranby's formal objects would not satisfy the test of an Aboriginal body under the ADC Act. Arrangements were made to have Tranby change its formal objects before making further payments to it.

In other words, the initial payment was illegal. Tranby was not legally entitled or legally able to receive that funding. So, what was going to happen was that the formal objects of the organisation were to be changed so that, somehow or other, retrospectively, something that had been illegal was to be rendered legitimate. The next episode in the saga comes in the form of Mr Adams, QC, who indicated in subsequent advisings:
. . . Tranby would satisfy the definition of an Aboriginal body but that it was not necessary because the treaty negotiations fell within ADC's general power in sub-section 9 (1) of the Act.

I raised with Senator Tate in the Senate early in December the question of inconsistencies between Mr Adams's advice and the advice of the Commission's own principal legal officer. I asked Senator Tate whether this matter had been referred to the Attorney-General's Department for subsequent advice and, if not, whether he would do so as a matter of urgency. He refused, quite obviously, to take any action on that aspect. Mr Hand also refused to take any action on that matter. According to the Auditor- General's report, as outlined at paragraph 2.3.40, the matter was referred to the Attorney-General's Department. That referral by Audit occurred in early February. The Attorney-General's Department disagreed with Mr Adams's advice and:

. . . expressed the opinion that the payments could not be regarded as coming within ADC's powers under section 24 or the other provisions of the Act. Audit accepts the Department's opinion and passed a copy of it to the ADC on 17 February . . .

We still have to hear the final response to that matter. But, on all the evidence to date, the payment of $377,000 to Tranby in August/September 1988 was an illegal transaction which was never properly processed within the Commission itself because it was all done without memorandum. When queries were raised by the Commission's own principal legal officer as to the legality of the payment, his questions were overridden by a QC whose advice was not even subsequently tested until the last two or three weeks. It was then found by the Attorney-General's Department to be incorrect advice. I will not pursue the Tranby matter any further at this stage other than to say that I believe that we will hear a great deal more of Tranby in the weeks ahead.
I move briefly now to another part of the report so as to have recorded in Hansard paragraph 3.4.9 which appears at page 70 of that report. This paragraph relates to policy guidelines. It says:

An examination of existing policy guidelines by the Working Party established that the guidelines were out of date, unrealistic, not relevant, not measureable, ambiguous and too narrow. The Department was budget rather than policy driven.

One could not have any more damning statement of the administrative incompetence of a government, a government department and a Minister of the Crown than that comment on the guidelines for the grants for so-called Aboriginal advancement.

The final point I make concerns the conclusions of the report regarding enterprise projects. Those conclusions are to be found on page 59 of the report. I read into Hansard paragraph 2.10.1, which says:

This audit has shown that (except in Imparja Television) there were serious defects in the particular enterprise projects queried by Senator Tambling and other members of Senate Estimates Committee E. There were also serious defects in many other projects examined in the audit. The audit disclosed that ADC's largest enterprise project, Yeperenye Shopping Centre, suffered from a fundamental flaw under the Act.

The comments and contents of this report bear out very strongly all the points that the Opposition has been making for months on this issue. They are points that have been reinforced in this report. It is, in other words, a report which absolutely and totally justifies the demand that we, on this side of the chamber, made months ago-well before Christmas-following the hearings of Estimates Committee E, that there was only one proper course for the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to take, and that was to resign. If he did not resign, the Prime Minister was bound to dismiss him. The report confirms that demand. I again demand the resignation of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission: Election

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 28 February 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, or officers acting for him, approached the Australian Electoral Commission to draw up a timetable for elections to be held in accordance with the provisions of Division 4 of Part III of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island Commission Bill 1988?
(2) In particular has the Minister proposed a date in accordance with clause 87 of the Bill?
(3) If the answer to question (1) or (2) is yes, what date and or timetable has the Electoral Commission agreed to or proposed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Officers of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs have discussed an election timetable with officers of the Australian Electoral Commission.

(3) The Australian Electoral Commission has proposed a timetable setting out the need for 92 days from the day the Commission receives a request to conduct an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission election until the day the result could be declared. This 92 day period could not commence, however, until all preliminary work has been completed. The preliminary work includes the setting of boundaries, the finalisation of election rules, and the preparation of all necessary election manuals, information, education and training materials. It also includes compilation of a roll if a roll is required. In addition, training of Commission and Department of Aboriginal Affairs staff would need to have commenced.
